predator@flagstaffcomms.com
Notes to Editors:
Predator is an oil & gas company with a portfolio of assets including unique and highly prospective onshore Moroccan gas exposure and production, appraisal and exploration projects onshore Trinidad.
Morocco offers a potentially faster route to commercialisation of shallow biogenic gas through a CNG or micro-LNG development. The structure penetrated by the MOU-1 and MOU-3 wells is currently defined as having the best potential for an application for an Exploitation Concession in 2026. The Company is committed to partnering with entities capable of supporting a future development decision and who have already identified the opportunity as one warranting the execution of a Collaboration Agreement and a Memorandum of Understanding. Moroccan gas prices are high, and the fiscal terms are some of the best in the world. The presence of gas export infrastructure adjacent to the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure allows for a scalable gas development after initial CNG or micro-LNG gas production over time establishes

data.author: PrivateTesla
data.content: This is better and faster than I was expecting. 100% retention. Looks like Trinidad is going to grow production quickly??

data.author: aimofthegame6
data.content: Good to see positive progress.

data.author: Footandmouth
data.content: Bowling along nicely 😀

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Just discussing this offline.  This bit: "demonstrate our in-house operational capabilities to ensure we are well-placed and qualified to acquire any new attractive opportunities that may or may not become available long-term"  is important - Heritage have just offered up sub-licences on the Moruga North, Tabaquite and PS-3 blocks, and will want to see that PRD can operate these themselves rather than just using an agency such as NABI.  imho of course.

data.author: Silverfoil13
data.content: Interesting to see SML raise £4 million at full market price announced this morning. No dilution. Shame PRD can’t do that.

data.author: AmyStake
data.content: Production at Trinidad growing fast :)

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: Excellent news & taking  the lower  production forecast , it isn’t going to take very long to pay back the money raised ….. thanks PG

data.author: pashtronical
data.content: Let’s get drilling. Gl all

data.author: Porters1
data.content: Will the 300 -400 bopd increase all be new production of which prd will get 7.5%. Drill it down to facts it's not that great an increase its easy to see why they have went 100% on snowcap3

data.author: sygmaa
data.content: This announcement just two days after the other one... 1500 to 2000 barrels/day by the end of 2026? The 1000 barrel target has been completely blown out of the water. And a nice fiscal recovery to boot

data.author: Porters1
data.content: Rampers where all over this forum from the start of the year. Prd was overvalued when the placing was done hence the discount.

data.author: Lancygeo
data.content: PG is clearly building an empire in Trinidad….block by block 😊

data.author: Gudin
data.content: This will add around 30 bpd to PRD until the costs are recovered and 60bpd after than unspecified timeframe. A welcome addition but more steady growth than empire building.

data.author: InJamesweTrust
data.content: Wonder how much a drill and flow test in Guercif would have cost and yet strangely small increments in T&T pursued instead of the T-Rex proposition. How much has he raised and diluted shareholder by without proving it up. £20m and probably 4-500m shares at a guess since Oct'23 ish.

data.author: Obadhia
data.content: Much rather hear about progress, not intentions, with our Moroccan operations, you know the real meaningful stuff we've always placed massive value on.

data.author: Rustyrat1970
data.content: Drilling has actually started in Trinidad — BON-18 is turning to the right, not just another “planned” RNS. That matters. This isn’t talk anymore, it’s execution !! The programme laid out is material: multiple development wells at Bonasse, workovers at Goudron, and all of it feeding into Snowcap-3. Management are clearly pushing to build production first, using existing infrastructure, which is exactly what the market has been asking for. I like many believed  the placing hurt, but it’s also now done. Crucially it funds this entire drilling and workover campaign while keeping 100% ownership. No farm-out, no fire sale. That tells me PG believes the upside is worth retaining. Today’s action also says a lot: despite the knock, the majority of trades are buys. That doesn’t look like panic, it looks like believers like me using weakness to top up ahead of results. If they deliver even the lower end of the forecast 300–400 bopd uplift, the current valuation looks very tight. Results now matter more than words and we are finally moving into a results phase. data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Oil production: 30/11/25 308 bopd. 4 January 2026 367 bopd. 20 January 2026 387 bopd. Today's combined programme's forecasts are expected to add between 300 and 400 bopd. Existing production is currently 387. Forecasted production 350/400. That makes 737/787bopd. (This is without snowcap 3). That's just the work over the next six to eight weeks. Let that sink in. The scale of growth is impressive and will continue to add real value. PG has set up an excellent money earner with NABI. The one financial downside is  the deal with the operator. It made perfect business sense at the time to let them take the initial development risk. It was a win, win for both sides. However yesterday's fund raise shows a change in direction where Predator will not share the bigger prizes like Snowcap 3. On this drill they will take all the profit. Hence the fund raise. I can't remember what the anticipated return from snowcap 3 is? (a figure would be appreciated), but if successful, it will transform Trinidad into a solid money earning company. The main complaint with Predator is that they have promised much but delivered nothing in value. This is no longer true and the market will respond to a company making millions in oil production. Just need to see the placement shares churned. Then it's full steam ahead! This new money steam will give PG a powerful negotiating hand in Morocco.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Oil production: 30/11/25 308 bopd. 4 January 2026 367 bopd. 20 January 2026 387 bopd. Bonasse field: Agreement with NABI. NABI will commence this month drilling the deeper TPD-CD1 to 1800 feet in the Bonasse field. Goudron field: High-potential infield development well and two heavy workovers in Goudron field to commence within the next month (7th January comment). Snowcap1: Snowcap-1, drilled and tested in 2010/11, tested the topmost sand (#8 Sand). The 6-foot sand flowed at initial rates of 1100 to 1450 bopd before stabilising at a rate of 500 bopd. In the Snowcap-1 well the primary basal Herrera #1 and #2 sands were missed due to being faulted out. Snowcap 3: Drilling and testing Snowcap-3 ("SC-3") appraisal and development well , operated solely by the Company, will evaluate the gross 600-foot Herrea reservoir interval that contains 8 very good quality reservoirs that produced in the former BP Moruga West field x kms to the SE. SC-3 location has been selected to penetrate an unfaulted section with good potential for a thickened #1 Sand. The well is scheduled for Q2 2026 and is expected to take up to 20 days to drill and log to a depth of approximately 5300 feet. It is intended to put the well in production in Q3 2026 after drilling and testing completes. SC-3 will potentially unlock the 3P resources for the Herra #1, #2# 3 and #4 Sands of 56.9MM barrels of oil. Why the raise?: The work overs, carried out by Predator's well operator, are showing excellent returns. This is a risk free venue (to Predator) however the return is lower due to the operator taking the main financial risk. Predator have decided that on the more profitable well they are not going to let the operating drillers take the main profit. Today's decision shows that PG is confident of a successful return. 1000bopd is just a starting point The profit will now be a lot higher due to  the fund raise. The raise also gives Predator financial independence and funds to move forward. Trinidad is becoming a revenue stream with oil production increasing every month. Morocco is still ongoing. Ireland is not dead. However, this share is not for the faint hearted ! Good fortune and stay strong over the next few months.

data.author: welloilbeefooked
data.content: I had a little chat with my AI pal as follows : Market reaction to the Predator Oil & Gas RNS this morning has been to drop the share price by around 25% , looks like news may have leaked as there was also a sharp drop yesterday afternoon prior to the rns this morning. Paul Griffiths is the largest shareholder in PRD and has seen a massive paper loss on his shareholding today. He must have known the effect the dilution would cause as this has happened several times in the past. Is this raise going to be exceptionally accretive for shareholders?  Why else would PG do this when he could have allowed NABI to conduct the drilling and just let predator take the normal revenue share? The sharp share price drop in Predator Oil & Gas (PRD) leading up to the January 20, 2026 RNS suggests the market was "sniffing out" a dilutive event. While a 30% drop is painful, your theory that Paul Griffiths (the largest individual shareholder at ~6.7%) is doing this for long-term accretion is backed by the specific structure of the NABI Master Services Agreement (MSA). Here is the "Rational Investor" breakdown of why Paul Griffiths chose dilution today over the NABI partnership for the Snowcap-3 (SC-3) well. 1. 100% Ownership vs. 30% Revenue Share The most critical reason for this raise is equity ownership of the "Moonshot." The NABI Model: Under the existing MSA, NABI funds the drilling and workovers in fields like Bonasse and Goudron. In return, Predator only receives 30% of gross revenues (dropping to 15% during cost recovery). The SC-3 "Sole Op" Model: Today's RNS explicitly states that SC-3 will be "operated solely by the Company." By raising £4.5 million, Paul Griffiths is ensuring that Predator keeps 100% of the interest in the potential 56.9 million barrels of 3P resources. The Maths: If SC-3 is a hit and produces 1,000 bopd, 100% of that cash flow belongs to Predator shareholders rather than being split with a contractor. For the largest shareholder, a 15% dilution today is a small price to pay to avoid "giving away" 70% of the upside on the company’s most valuable well.

data.author: welloilbeefooked
data.content: Contd.... 2. Protecting the "Major" M&A Valuation Griffiths’ commentary highlights his goal of attracting Oil Majors (BP, Shell, Exxon). Clean Assets: Majors prefer buying companies with high working interests and "clean" operations. If Predator had NABI funding SC-3, any potential buyer would have to negotiate with NABI to "buy out" their revenue share. Operational Proof: By drilling SC-3 themselves, Predator proves they have the technical and financial "know-how" to manage high-impact appraisal wells. This increases the "Premium" a Major might pay in a buyout scenario. 3. Why Now? The "Funding Gap" Reality While the company previously stated it was "fully funded," that usually applies to minimum license commitments. Discretionary vs. Mandatory: Infill drilling like TPD CD1 is mandatory/funded via NABI. SC-3 is a discretionary appraisal. The Balance Sheet: As of mid-2025, Predator’s loss widened to £1.9m. With production at 387 bopd, the company is generating revenue but not yet enough "Free Cash" to write a £3 million cheque for a 5,300-foot appraisal well. The Strategic Reset: By raising £4.5m at 3.5p, Griffiths has "reset" the valuation but removed the financing risk. The company is now a "funded producer" rather than a "starved producer." Summary: The Accretive Bet This raise is intended to be exceptionally accretive. Paul Griffiths has essentially "traded" 15% of the company's equity for the cash to keep 100% of the Snowcap prize. If SC-3 hits the #1 and #2 sands and moves 20M barrels into the 2P category, the value added to the company would be worth many times the £4.5m raised. For a medium-term investor, the 3.5p entry price (post-placing) represents a valuation that essentially ignores the 57-million-barrel upside.

data.content: Dsymons - instead of posting complete lies, do a bit of cursory research - another one in the bin! Here's what i have found on PG purchases after one quick search,  there are probably others but I can't be bothered  - 1. Direct Market Purchases (Cash Outlay) These are "on-market" buys where he used personal funds to purchase shares at the prevailing market price: May 2023: Purchased 3,328,119 shares at 10.0p (Investment: ~£332,800). November 2022: Two purchases totaling 7,855,486 shares at an average of ~3.9p (Investment: ~£304,600). February 2020: Purchased 312,500 shares at 4.0p (Investment: ~£12,500). 2. Option Exercises (Capital Injection) While options are "incentives," exercising them requires the director to pay the exercise price to the company. This acts as a direct injection of cash into the business: February 2025: Exercised 18.5 million options at 5.0p (Cash paid to company: £925,000). May 2023: Exercised 7,855,486 options at 8.0p (Cash paid to company: £628,400).

data.author: blissful
data.content: Surfit. Most people lose money on these small companies, it takes timing and not believing everything a director says. For instance, 'we are fully funded,' means, 'for day to day business but if we have a chance we will go to the market for more'. You don't need to give up investing, but be very selective in the companies you chose and keep to a few so you know what is happening. Be extra wary of AIM. These are not recommendations but they are companies that will almost certainly keep up their success rate this year. Pan African resources (PAF) - gold miner. Just take a look at the chart. They pay a small dividend but in these difficult times people are buying gold in large amounts, countries are buy it - do some research on this and check out PAF, they are growing and growing with good profits. Hochschild Mining. Another brilliant gold miner. Foresight (FSG). Just gone XD and give a really good div of 6.1% today. Had a sharp fall to 400p due to excellent results which is when I bought, and is now catching up. The dividend is worth reinvesting over and over again so this is a possibility for a pension in coming years, it's a gem. You need insurance and so does just about everyone. Phoenix (PHNX) currently 7.31 dividend is a no brainer, take a look at the chart - up and up. Okay, down today due to Trump but it will fly back. I bought Chesnara (CHS) years ago and they dish out money to me twice a year with a dividend of 7.24 %at todays prices. There are loads of other like LAND, LMP, MNG, LGEN. They all seem to go up bit by bit and give excellent yields which makes investing fun. Treat companies like PRD like you would a one arm bandit, you may get lucky, you may not. Even BATS are going strong although I sold up as I had a really good run with them but I have a target to get back in as I like the quarterly dividends. All the best and have a great time getting to know some well run companies. The odd one will run aground but there's usually a warning from those in the know.

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: There's nothing like a night's sleep to help look at things more objectively and try to separate the two components of investing – logic and emotion. I'm sure many reacted with negative emotion seeing a steeply discounted placing sharply reducing the holding value of their investment – I certainly did, it's not a pleasant feeling seeing your portfolio value reduced by a six-figure sum overnight.  There's also the knowledge that this will create an overhang that will take some time to clear, and that a full recovery may not happen until something material is announced. How about some logic, some basic arithmetic?  Monday lunchtime, there were 843 M fully-diluted shares (inc unexercised warrants & options), changing hands at 5.25p, giving a market capitalisation of £44.3M.  That's what people thought the company was worth. By last night's close, the fully-diluted number had risen to 980.6M, and there was an additional net £4.2M in the kitty.  44.3 + 4.2 = 48.5.  Divide that by 980.6, and the current share price should logically be 4.95p rather than 3.45p.  Why isn't it? – emotive response, of course. Logically, it should be a little higher than this, since the pathway to drilling Snowcap-3 is now clear, and PRD are going to receive all the income from the well, rather than sharing that with the rig owner as previously mooted. So, what will kick the share price back up to the proper level, after the placing overhang is mopped up?  After so many false starts and delayed promises, PG has finally to pull a real live rabbit out of the hat. His chances are good.  For the next six months, there are a number of potential rabbits: *  The MOU-1 / MOU-3 biogenic gas ITR we were promised Jan/Feb. *  Now a new ITR just for the TGB-6 Sands. *  A biogenic gas sourced CNG agreement; an LNG agreement; or perhaps both. *  Possible divestment of the 81km² TGB-6 resource as a separate project. *  A larger scale Morocco divestment, for which we are over halfway through the six-month timescale. *  Snowcap-1 re-entry in March, which should include use of dewaxer and help to derisk SC-3. *  Snowcap-3 drilling & testing in April/May, connection to production Q3.  At 500-1000 bopd, that gives annual revenue of $10-20M.  Nice. Plus a few baby rabbits (kits?) to include progress in Trinidad; and potential acquisition of additional producing fields in Trinidad & Guyana.  I accept that these won't move the needle much, but are still positives. Hopefully the 'woe is me' will evaporate quickly, and be replaced – apparently for at least one person here – with the fabled 'hookers & cocaine', but as our governments like to remind us, please always copulate & inhale responsibly.

data.content: There's been several posters putting forward the idea that PRD effectively only gets 7.5% of new oil revenue and 15% of old. A bit of research shows thatt is almost certainly incorrect and we get the full 15% and 30% respectively. the Master Services Agreement (MSA) is a contract between the Parent Company (Predator Oil & Gas Holdings PLC) and NABI. Because it is a service-based royalty agreement, the money flows to the Parent before it ever reaches the "net profit" line of the subsidiary where the 51/49 split with WIEGL would occur.1. The Proof: Key RNS DocumentsYou can find these documents on any financial portal (Investegate, London Stock Exchange, or the PRD website). Here are the specific dates and the "smoking gun" quotes:RNS DateDocument TitleThe Conclusive QuoteJan 7, 2026Trinidad Increased Production"Predator receives 30% of gross sales revenues from existing production less taxes and royalties and 15% of new production until recovery of NABI costs... Predator has no exposure to current and future field operating costs."Sept 1, 2025Completion of Acquisition"In accordance with the PAFSMA, the Company [Predator] will receive 30% of gross sales receipts at the sales point... with no exposure to field operating costs."Dec 16, 2025End of Year Operations Update"Predator receives 30% of gross sales revenues... after restructuring of the companies acquired in 2025. This provides for more efficient utilisation of legacy tax losses."2. Why it doesn't get split 51/49 with WIEGLIn the February 18, 2025 RNS (Acquisition of Challenger Assets), the structure was finalized. The reason you don't halving that 15% or 30% is due to the legal definition of the payment:The "Top-Slice" vs. "Bottom-Line": A 51/49 split applies to Dividends (money left over after all bills are paid). But the 15/30% is a Gross Revenue Share. It is taken right at the "sales point" (the South Erin gathering station).The Parent Contract: The MSA is held by the PLC. NABI pays the PLC a "management fee" (the 15/30%) in exchange for the right to operate the fields.The "Zero-Margin" Sub: Because NABI takes 70% and Predator takes 30% of the gross revenue, the subsidiary (Caribbean Rex) technically has zero net income from those barrels. Therefore, there is nothing for WIEGL to take 49% of in that specific transaction.3. The "Tax Shield" ConfirmationThe December 16, 2025 RNS also confirms that Predator uses its $48 million in tax losses against this revenue. Since those tax losses are owned by the Predator group, it further proves that the revenue is being booked by Predator. If the money were being split 51/49 at the sub-level, Predator wouldn't be able to apply its full tax shield to WIEGL's half of the money.Summary of the "Conclusive" RealityPredator's Take: 15% (New) / 30% (Old) of Gross Sales.WIEGL's Take: 0% of that specific 15/30% slice. They make their money by providing the services/equipment used by the JV and their "Change of Control" payout.The Risk: The only person losing

data.author: welloilbeefooked
data.content: Contd.... The only person losing out in this structure is the "Subsidiary" itself, which remains a low-value shell while the Parent (PRD) and the Contractor (NABI) take all the cash. DYOR

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Oil production: 30/11/25 308 bopd. 4 January 2026 367 bopd. 20 January 2026 387 bopd. Bonasse field: Agreement with NABI. NABI will commence this month drilling the deeper TPD-CD1 to 1800 feet in the Bonasse field. Goudron field: High-potential infield development well and two heavy workovers in Goudron field to commence within the next month (7th January comment). Snowcap1: Snowcap-1, drilled and tested in 2010/11, tested the topmost sand (#8 Sand). The 6-foot sand flowed at initial rates of 1100 to 1450 bopd before stabilising at a rate of 500 bopd. In the Snowcap-1 well the primary basal Herrera #1 and #2 sands were missed due to being faulted out. Snowcap 3: Drilling and testing Snowcap-3 ("SC-3") appraisal and development well , operated solely by the Company, will evaluate the gross 600-foot Herrea reservoir interval that contains 8 very good quality reservoirs that produced in the former BP Moruga West field x kms to the SE. SC-3 location has been selected to penetrate an unfaulted section with good potential for a thickened #1 Sand. The well is scheduled for Q2 2026 and is expected to take up to 20 days to drill and log to a depth of approximately 5300 feet. It is intended to put the well in production in Q3 2026 after drilling and testing completes. SC-3 will potentially unlock the 3P resources for the Herra #1, #2# 3 and #4 Sands of 56.9MM barrels of oil. Why the raise?: The work overs, carried out by Predator's well operator, are showing excellent returns. This is a risk free venue (to Predator) however the return is lower due to the operator taking the main financial risk. Predator have decided that on the more profitable well they are not going to let the operating drillers take the main profit. Today's decision shows that PG is confident of a successful return. 1000bopd is just a starting point The profit will now be a lot higher due to  the fund raise. The raise also gives Predator financial independence and funds to move forward. Trinidad is becoming a revenue stream with oil production increasing every month. Morocco is still ongoing. Ireland is not dead. However, this share is not for the faint hearted ! Good fortune and stay strong over the next few months.

data.author: welloilbeefooked
data.content: I had a little chat with my AI pal as follows : Market reaction to the Predator Oil & Gas RNS this morning has been to drop the share price by around 25% , looks like news may have leaked as there was also a sharp drop yesterday afternoon prior to the rns this morning. Paul Griffiths is the largest shareholder in PRD and has seen a massive paper loss on his shareholding today. He must have known the effect the dilution would cause as this has happened several times in the past. Is this raise going to be exceptionally accretive for shareholders?  Why else would PG do this when he could have allowed NABI to conduct the drilling and just let predator take the normal revenue share? The sharp share price drop in Predator Oil & Gas (PRD) leading up to the January 20, 2026 RNS suggests the market was "sniffing out" a dilutive event. While a 30% drop is painful, your theory that Paul Griffiths (the largest individual shareholder at ~6.7%) is doing this for long-term accretion is backed by the specific structure of the NABI Master Services Agreement (MSA). Here is the "Rational Investor" breakdown of why Paul Griffiths chose dilution today over the NABI partnership for the Snowcap-3 (SC-3) well. 1. 100% Ownership vs. 30% Revenue Share The most critical reason for this raise is equity ownership of the "Moonshot." The NABI Model: Under the existing MSA, NABI funds the drilling and workovers in fields like Bonasse and Goudron. In return, Predator only receives 30% of gross revenues (dropping to 15% during cost recovery). The SC-3 "Sole Op" Model: Today's RNS explicitly states that SC-3 will be "operated solely by the Company." By raising £4.5 million, Paul Griffiths is ensuring that Predator keeps 100% of the interest in the potential 56.9 million barrels of 3P resources. The Maths: If SC-3 is a hit and produces 1,000 bopd, 100% of that cash flow belongs to Predator shareholders rather than being split with a contractor. For the largest shareholder, a 15% dilution today is a small price to pay to avoid "giving away" 70% of the upside on the company’s most valuable well.

data.author: welloilbeefooked
data.content: Contd.... 2. Protecting the "Major" M&A Valuation Griffiths’ commentary highlights his goal of attracting Oil Majors (BP, Shell, Exxon). Clean Assets: Majors prefer buying companies with high working interests and "clean" operations. If Predator had NABI funding SC-3, any potential buyer would have to negotiate with NABI to "buy out" their revenue share. Operational Proof: By drilling SC-3 themselves, Predator proves they have the technical and financial "know-how" to manage high-impact appraisal wells. This increases the "Premium" a Major might pay in a buyout scenario. 3. Why Now? The "Funding Gap" Reality While the company previously stated it was "fully funded," that usually applies to minimum license commitments. Discretionary vs. Mandatory: Infill drilling like TPD CD1 is mandatory/funded via NABI. SC-3 is a discretionary appraisal. The Balance Sheet: As of mid-2025, Predator’s loss widened to £1.9m. With production at 387 bopd, the company is generating revenue but not yet enough "Free Cash" to write a £3 million cheque for a 5,300-foot appraisal well. The Strategic Reset: By raising £4.5m at 3.5p, Griffiths has "reset" the valuation but removed the financing risk. The company is now a "funded producer" rather than a "starved producer." Summary: The Accretive Bet This raise is intended to be exceptionally accretive. Paul Griffiths has essentially "traded" 15% of the company's equity for the cash to keep 100% of the Snowcap prize. If SC-3 hits the #1 and #2 sands and moves 20M barrels into the 2P category, the value added to the company would be worth many times the £4.5m raised. For a medium-term investor, the 3.5p entry price (post-placing) represents a valuation that essentially ignores the 57-million-barrel upside.

data.author: welloilbeefooked
data.content: Dsymons - instead of posting complete lies, do a bit of cursory research - another one in the bin! Here's what i have found on PG purchases after one quick search,  there are probably others but I can't be bothered  - 1. Direct Market Purchases (Cash Outlay) These are "on-market" buys where he used personal funds to purchase shares at the prevailing market price: May 2023: Purchased 3,328,119 shares at 10.0p (Investment: ~£332,800). November 2022: Two purchases totaling 7,855,486 shares at an average of ~3.9p (Investment: ~£304,600). February 2020: Purchased 312,500 shares at 4.0p (Investment: ~£12,500). 2. Option Exercises (Capital Injection) While options are "incentives," exercising them requires the director to pay the exercise price to the company. This acts as a direct injection of cash into the business: February 2025: Exercised 18.5 million options at 5.0p (Cash paid to company: £925,000). May 2023: Exercised 7,855,486 options at 8.0p (Cash paid to company: £628,400).

data.content: Hey, Keith. Had a little look into hyperspectural satellites for hydrocarbons. I am so glad you are here to put many things in to small bite, layman’s terms. My head hurts Reading such as…. The radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction and orthorectification were done on ENVI + IDL (version 5.3) software (Harris Geospatial Solutions, Inc., Broomfield, CO, USA). The stripe noise removal was carried out by the full image stripe noise removal method (Tan et al., Citation2005). The calculation formula of this method is 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘=𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘+𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 /𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 −𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑚𝑘 , ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑠𝑘 where 𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the radiation value of the i column and j line in the K band; 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the corrected radiation value; the 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column; 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, i column; ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column of the reference image; ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, the i column of the reference image. The 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘 is the sensor gain and the 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 is the offset; ¯ 𝑚𝑘 is the mean value of the whole image in the K band; ¯ In plain English, Will  I be rich one day? 🤔 𝑠𝑘 is the mean standard deviation of the whole image in the K band.

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 2. Hyperspectral satellite data (which I have not seen, but I trust the interpretation I have been given) shows abundant gas underground in the whole area.  This data cannot indicate the depth of the gas source, so even were there no actual gas in the Jurassic, this suggests that the underlying Triassic is gas-charged. Across N. Africa, the TAGI is one of the most prolific sources of hydrocarbons.  It was known (from the above work by PG) to be at Tendrara.  Here the main TAGI is at a depth of 2600 – 2800m.  Well TE-6 shows 28m net of reservoir, TE-10 has 10m net, 110m gross.  TE-7 & TE-8 show hundreds of metres gross depth.  The problem is that at Tendrara the reservoir quality is poor, with 8% porosity, as opposed to up to 15% elsewhere.  This requires mechanical stimulation (fracking / acidizing) for commercial flow.  Interestingly, the same satellite data referred to above was ignored by SOU's James Parsons, resulting in the Tendrara drills being sub-optimally positioned. From what I can tell from the limited seismic data publicly available, the top of the Guercif Triassic is about 1000m closer to the surface than at Tendrara.  This will not only be cheaper to drill, but also likely to be less compacted, resulting in improved reservoir quality.  PG is probably the best qualified person on Earth to make that call, but I assume he has weighed up the cost : benefit potential for large, well sealed Triassic reservoirs as opposed to complex Jurassic structures, hence the change in near-term strategy. "When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?" John Maynard Keynes.
data.thread_title: RE: Why the new emphasis on the Triassic?

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 1. @MwoQ.  Great to see a new contributor, especially one asking an interesting question that I'm sure others have also wondered about. The view has been expressed on here by the usual suspects that there is no gas in the Jurassic, so 'bait & switch' has moved attention somewhere else, in this case the Triassic.  I don't agree with that, although of course what follows is my own personal interpretation. Paul Griffiths has a vastly more comprehensive view of these matters – after his MSc on 'Late Mesozoic seismic sequence stratigraphy of NE Libya' he worked for the Libyan National Oil Company and Gulf Oil evaluating exactly the potential reservoirs PRD are working on today.  Later in his career he worked up the initial evaluation of the TAGI opportunity at Tendrara, 125km south of Guercif, which will be producing for Sound / Mana later this year. First, we need to understand the complexity of the Jurassic carbonate.  The Titanosaurus structure is basically a huge fossil coral reef, laid down in waters of varying depth over millions of years.  When the water was deep, sediment would mostly be fine-grained, resulting in dense rock with poor hydrocarbon reservoir potential.  In shallow water, coral reef proper would form, and this rock, already of sponge-like texture, would be further eroded by periodic exposure to the air and/or waves.  This exposure results in leached porosity development - which means what it says – increased pores and cavities resulting in excellent capacity as a hydrocarbon reservoir.  From this, it can be seen there will be vertically stacked high potential reservoirs alternating with non-productive strata.  Added to this complexity is the likelihood of horizontal variation – think of many reefs separated by infilled channels. Directly beneath the Jurassic is the top of the Triassic – marked by a thick layer of salt resulting from the evaporation of part of the ancient Tethys Sea, of which the Med forms a small remnant.  This salt acts as a very viscous liquid, moving upwards and sideways due to the pressure of overlying rock. This layer is impervious to gas, so forms an excellent seal for any gas reservoirs beneath.  However, the seismic wave conduction velocities of rock salt and carbonate reservoir are very similar, making them difficult to distinguish. The seismic data available to PRD is not that great, tbh. As a result, MOU-5 was drilled into a laterally mobilised salt layer, not carbonate reservoir.  It seems that the particular part of Titanosaurus that was drilled has been isolated from gas migration by salt above, below and laterally.  Correlation of drilled material with the seismic data has resulted in a greatly improved understanding of the structure.  There is every possibility that the structure contains multiple TCF of gas, but will require more detailed geophysical evaluation, which will cost more than PRD can afford – hence the farm in process currently underway.

data.author: JoshW7
data.content: Welcome to the board ManWithoutQual. Rather like you I'm no O&G expert either, my take on your question is Predator’s recent messaging emphasises the TAGI reservoirs rather than the Jurassic, not because the Jurassic has lost value but because TAGI offers a faster, lower‑risk route to commercial gas. TAGI wells are shallower and cheaper to drill. The Jurassic remains a large, high‑impact target, but drilling it requires more capital, deeper wells, and potentially a partner. By proving TAGI commerciality first, Predator strengthens its negotiating position and de‑risks the basin. The shift is strategic sequencing: TAGI now, Jurassic later as the transformational upside. I'm sure others will chip in with their take on it too but that's my starter for 10.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: I did find this from TW’s  copilot: “Here’s a clear, trader‑level breakdown of what the order book was almost certainly doing today. 📘 Level 2 Behaviour Assessment for PRD.L (Today) 🧩 1. Tight Spread = Balanced Book PRD.L traded in a very narrow range (3.40p–3.50p) with the mid-price barely moving. A tight spread like that usually means: Market makers were well-supplied on both sides No aggressive buyers lifting the ask No aggressive sellers hitting the bid This is classic neutral order book behaviour. 📈 2. High Volume, No Price Movement = Absorption Volume was 3× the daily average, yet the price barely moved. That strongly suggests: Large buy orders were being absorbed by resting sell liquidity, or Large sell orders were being absorbed by resting buy liquidity This is called absorption, and it’s a hallmark of: Accumulation Distribution Position rotation Market makers managing inventory If this were retail-driven volume, the price would have moved more. 🧱 3. Likely Large Iceberg Orders When you see: High volume Flat price Tight spread …it often means iceberg orders (hidden size) were sitting at key levels. Most likely: 3.40p had a large hidden buyer 3.50p had a large hidden seller This creates a “volume box” where price gets trapped. 🔄 4. Repeated Prints at the Same Price This pattern usually indicates: Market makers refreshing orders Algo participation Institutional accumulation/distribution If you saw lots of trades at 3.45p–3.48p, that’s a sign of: VWAP algos TWAP algos Liquidity-seeking algos These keep the price pinned. 🧭 5. What This Means for Traders This type of order book behaviour usually precedes one of two things: Scenario A — Accumulation If buyers were absorbing sells: Price will break upward once the seller is cleared Volume spike with no drop is bullish Scenario B — Distribution If sellers were absorbing buys: Price will break downward once the buyer is filled Volume spike with no rise is bearish Right now, the book behaviour is neutral-to-accumulative, because: Price did not weaken despite heavy volume No sign of bid collapse No widening spreads That leans slightly bullish. 🎯 Summary Today’s Level 2 behaviour for PRD.L likely showed: Tight spreads Heavy liquidity at 3.40p and 3.50p Iceberg orders absorbing flow Market makers keeping price boxed High volume without directional movement This is classic positioning ahead of news or institutional accumulation.”

data.author: ManWithoutQual
data.content: I'm a long time lurker on this board who has decided to finally jump into the arena. I first invested in PRD after the MOU-2 drill, so while I haven't been involved in PRD as long as some posters, I do have my fair share of scars! I've been accumulating steadily since MOU-2 and have amassed 1.3 million shares. While this may be a pittance compared to others, PRD is my largest single company investment so it matters a great deal to me and I take it seriously. Over the last several years I have been working consistently to gain a better understanding of my investment and I deeply appreciate the knowledgeable contributions of so many posters here. I am neither a financial expert or advisor nor am I an oil and gas expert, I've spent my career building software (including AI before it became the Messiah), but I love to learn and find the whole oil and gas sector utterly fascinating. My interest was first peaked during the shale boom when I was working at a cloud company in Texas and we kicked off a number of discussions with O&G producers about utilizing Permian and Eagle Ford gas to power our data centers. I realize that the sentiment here isn't great after the most recent raise. I confess to have taken it as a gut punch initially. I was expecting the next RNS to be the new ITR and based on the 17 December 2025 "End of Year Operations Update" I was not expecting a placement for any Trinidad operations. But any placing is only dilutive if it's not ultimately accretive. Raising money to engage in operations that have revenue potential is far different from raising money for general corporate purposes. I understand how frustrating delays can be - 2024 and 2025 tried my patience severely - but I am also a student of history, and it strikes me that oil and gas discovery, appraisal, and development is rarely the untrammeled movement from success to success. Pick a field, dig into its history, and you will see that more often than not. Now that I've pontificated enough, I'm onto my question: it seems as though the Jurassic potential is no longer being highlighted despite the fact that there may be untapped potential in other parts of the structure. Instead, the Company is focusing more on the TAGI. Would be interested to hear the opinions of others on the subject. Thanks.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: Sorry Rob. Good find! Found this part interesting! What the placing changes: From a market perspective, the raise alters the near-term picture in several practical ways. Key takeaways post-placing Near-term work programme funded Capital raised ahead of activity, not in response to it Reduced financing overhang during an active operational period Newsflow expected across multiple operations rather than a single event Predator retains 100% ownership of Snowcap-3, maintaining full exposure to any upside The Trinidad programme is sequenced, with multiple wells and workovers planned rather than a one-off Historical flow data combined with improved well placement underpins the Snowcap-3 appraisal rationale Taken together, this shifts the focus from funding uncertainty toward execution. Before any formal appraisal outcome, investors would typically expect a sequence of operational updates rather than a single standalone result. This often includes: Initial drilling update Confirmation of spud Progress toward target depth Early operational observations, where relevant Logging and reservoir evaluation Confirmation that logs have been run Initial indications of reservoir thickness and quality Commentary that is often qualitative rather than fully quantified at first Operational / testing update Flow testing plans or results (if undertaken) Completion status Decisions around tie-in or next operational steps Interesting times ahead !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I note an increase of filtered posts, so a  reminder of where we are. Trinidad: With the last update, the existing production was 387bopd. Forecasted production is an addition 350/400 bopd. That makes 737/787bopd. That's just the work over the next six to eight weeks by NABI. There will also be revenue from Snowcap 3 shortly. Testing results early Q3. The flow rate is expected to be between 500/1000 bopd, resulting in a revenue, per month, of one/two million. This revenue will not be shared with NABI and is the main reason for the fund raise. The revenue from Snowcap 3 should  quickly recover the placement money. Predator will be using their own T38 refurbished rig. There will then be 2 rigs and teams pushing on with work-overs and new drills! 2000bopd is very doable in the near future. Morocco: We await updated reports and news on negotiations January/February: An updated Independent Technical Resources report ,which will take into consideration the studies completed in 2025, is likely to uplift gas resources for the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure. Validation of the NuTech interpretation of gas saturations is also likely to significantly increase potential for prospective gas resources beyond the limits of the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure in the interval down to 950 metres. A fully-funded Environmental Impact Assessment will be commenced for a CNG/micro-LNG development together with a preliminary Front End Engineering Design concept. Desktop well design and drilling programme will be finalised for an appraisal/development well. The purpose of the fully-funded desktop work during this period is to ensure that the Company and its shareholders get the best possible mutually acceptable terms in commercial negotiations to monetise the discovered gas with the existing entities agreeing to join the Company in a potential FID and development programme. ‌A successful application for an Exploitation Concession in 2026 will crystalise the considerable value currently assigned to the discovered gas in Guercif licence area. Nothing is certain but Predator are moving forward with confidence. There will be a few weeks of churning the placement shares. The unwashed  will do their best to spread panic and fear. However, the reality is: The future is looking really encouraging.with real progress being made on a daily basis.

The above figure of 814,857,814 should be used by shareholders in the Company as the denominator for the calculations by which they will determine if they are required to notify their interest in, or a change to their interest in, the share capital of the Company under the Financial Conduct Authority's Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules.

Notes to Editors:
Predator is an oil & gas company with a diversified portfolio of scaled assets including unique and highly prospective onshore Moroccan gas exposure, with multiple fully financed upcoming catalysts.
Predator has an interesting gas project in Morocco with fast pace of commercialisation and significant upside. The Guercif project is a shallow CNG biogenic gas development with different traps and separate identified reservoirs. The Jurassic Titanosaurus is a shallow thermogenic gas prospect evaluating 249m of potential gross reservoir thickness in a trap of maximum closure of 187 km2 for pipeline gas to power, with pipeline 2.5km from wellhead. Moroccan gas prices are high, and the fiscal terms are some of the best in the world. Predator also has a diversified portfolio of assets across Ireland and Trinidad, which is a near-term revenue-generating project.
Predator has an experienced management team with particular knowledge in Moroccan sub surface and operations. The team specialises in incorporating modern, proven technologies and processes from Canada and the US to provinces where the conventional technologies did not allow their hydrocarbon potential to be revealed.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: predator oil & gas is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a compressed natural gas (cng) development project in morocco, focusing on the mou-3 well, which has shown potential for gas resources. the company is also preparing for a fully-funded environmental impact assessment for this cng development. energy-pedia.com **********.com overview of predator oil & gas in morocco predator oil & gas holdings is actively involved in the development of gas resources in morocco, particularly focusing on the guercif region. the company is working on a potential compressed natural gas (cng) project, which aims to monetize discovered gas reserves. current developments gas appraisal and development predator is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a final investment decision (fid) regarding gas appraisal and development. the mou-3 well has been identified as a key site for initial appraisal and potential development, focusing on the section above 950 meters. cng project plans discussions are ongoing with two parties for a fully-funded cng and/or micro-lng development. a fully-funded environmental impact assessment is set to commence for the cng/micro-lng development, along with preliminary engineering design concepts. financial position predator is fully funded to meet its commitments for the next twelve months, allowing it to accelerate its transition to production. the company has reported significant gas resources in the mou-1 and mou-3 wells, with estimates suggesting a potential standalone cng development project. future outlook the company aims to increase its production capacity and revenue through the successful implementation of its cng plans. the ongoing studies and testing are expected to enhance the understanding of gas saturations and improve the potential for gas resources in the region.

"Europa Oil & Gas (Holdings) plc, the AIM quoted West Africa, UK, and Ireland and focused oil and gas exploration, development and production company, is pleased to announce that it has received confirmation from the Irish Government's Department of Climate, Energy  and the Environment that, whilst the FEL 4/19 licence Phase 1 extension application is under consideration, it remains live and in Phase 1 until the application process is concluded. data.content: Hey, Keith. Had a little look into hyperspectural satellites for hydrocarbons. I am so glad you are here to put many things in to small bite, layman’s terms. My head hurts Reading such as…. The radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction and orthorectification were done on ENVI + IDL (version 5.3) software (Harris Geospatial Solutions, Inc., Broomfield, CO, USA). The stripe noise removal was carried out by the full image stripe noise removal method (Tan et al., Citation2005). The calculation formula of this method is 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘=𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘+𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 /𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 −𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑚𝑘 , ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑠𝑘 where 𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the radiation value of the i column and j line in the K band; 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the corrected radiation value; the 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column; 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, i column; ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column of the reference image; ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, the i column of the reference image. The 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘 is the sensor gain and the 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 is the offset; ¯ 𝑚𝑘 is the mean value of the whole image in the K band; ¯ In plain English, Will  I be rich one day? 🤔 𝑠𝑘 is the mean standard deviation of the whole image in the K band.

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 2. Hyperspectral satellite data (which I have not seen, but I trust the interpretation I have been given) shows abundant gas underground in the whole area.  This data cannot indicate the depth of the gas source, so even were there no actual gas in the Jurassic, this suggests that the underlying Triassic is gas-charged. Across N. Africa, the TAGI is one of the most prolific sources of hydrocarbons.  It was known (from the above work by PG) to be at Tendrara.  Here the main TAGI is at a depth of 2600 – 2800m.  Well TE-6 shows 28m net of reservoir, TE-10 has 10m net, 110m gross.  TE-7 & TE-8 show hundreds of metres gross depth.  The problem is that at Tendrara the reservoir quality is poor, with 8% porosity, as opposed to up to 15% elsewhere.  This requires mechanical stimulation (fracking / acidizing) for commercial flow.  Interestingly, the same satellite data referred to above was ignored by SOU's James Parsons, resulting in the Tendrara drills being sub-optimally positioned. From what I can tell from the limited seismic data publicly available, the top of the Guercif Triassic is about 1000m closer to the surface than at Tendrara.  This will not only be cheaper to drill, but also likely to be less compacted, resulting in improved reservoir quality.  PG is probably the best qualified person on Earth to make that call, but I assume he has weighed up the cost : benefit potential for large, well sealed Triassic reservoirs as opposed to complex Jurassic structures, hence the change in near-term strategy. "When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?" John Maynard Keynes.
data.thread_title: RE: Why the new emphasis on the Triassic?

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 1. @MwoQ.  Great to see a new contributor, especially one asking an interesting question that I'm sure others have also wondered about. The view has been expressed on here by the usual suspects that there is no gas in the Jurassic, so 'bait & switch' has moved attention somewhere else, in this case the Triassic.  I don't agree with that, although of course what follows is my own personal interpretation. Paul Griffiths has a vastly more comprehensive view of these matters – after his MSc on 'Late Mesozoic seismic sequence stratigraphy of NE Libya' he worked for the Libyan National Oil Company and Gulf Oil evaluating exactly the potential reservoirs PRD are working on today.  Later in his career he worked up the initial evaluation of the TAGI opportunity at Tendrara, 125km south of Guercif, which will be producing for Sound / Mana later this year. First, we need to understand the complexity of the Jurassic carbonate.  The Titanosaurus structure is basically a huge fossil coral reef, laid down in waters of varying depth over millions of years.  When the water was deep, sediment would mostly be fine-grained, resulting in dense rock with poor hydrocarbon reservoir potential.  In shallow water, coral reef proper would form, and this rock, already of sponge-like texture, would be further eroded by periodic exposure to the air and/or waves.  This exposure results in leached porosity development - which means what it says – increased pores and cavities resulting in excellent capacity as a hydrocarbon reservoir.  From this, it can be seen there will be vertically stacked high potential reservoirs alternating with non-productive strata.  Added to this complexity is the likelihood of horizontal variation – think of many reefs separated by infilled channels. Directly beneath the Jurassic is the top of the Triassic – marked by a thick layer of salt resulting from the evaporation of part of the ancient Tethys Sea, of which the Med forms a small remnant.  This salt acts as a very viscous liquid, moving upwards and sideways due to the pressure of overlying rock. This layer is impervious to gas, so forms an excellent seal for any gas reservoirs beneath.  However, the seismic wave conduction velocities of rock salt and carbonate reservoir are very similar, making them difficult to distinguish. The seismic data available to PRD is not that great, tbh. As a result, MOU-5 was drilled into a laterally mobilised salt layer, not carbonate reservoir.  It seems that the particular part of Titanosaurus that was drilled has been isolated from gas migration by salt above, below and laterally.  Correlation of drilled material with the seismic data has resulted in a greatly improved understanding of the structure.  There is every possibility that the structure contains multiple TCF of gas, but will require more detailed geophysical evaluation, which will cost more than PRD can afford – hence the farm in process currently underway.

data.author: JoshW7
data.content: Welcome to the board ManWithoutQual. Rather like you I'm no O&G expert either, my take on your question is Predator’s recent messaging emphasises the TAGI reservoirs rather than the Jurassic, not because the Jurassic has lost value but because TAGI offers a faster, lower‑risk route to commercial gas. TAGI wells are shallower and cheaper to drill. The Jurassic remains a large, high‑impact target, but drilling it requires more capital, deeper wells, and potentially a partner. By proving TAGI commerciality first, Predator strengthens its negotiating position and de‑risks the basin. The shift is strategic sequencing: TAGI now, Jurassic later as the transformational upside. I'm sure others will chip in with their take on it too but that's my starter for 10.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: I did find this from TW’s  copilot: “Here’s a clear, trader‑level breakdown of what the order book was almost certainly doing today. 📘 Level 2 Behaviour Assessment for PRD.L (Today) 🧩 1. Tight Spread = Balanced Book PRD.L traded in a very narrow range (3.40p–3.50p) with the mid-price barely moving. A tight spread like that usually means: Market makers were well-supplied on both sides No aggressive buyers lifting the ask No aggressive sellers hitting the bid This is classic neutral order book behaviour. 📈 2. High Volume, No Price Movement = Absorption Volume was 3× the daily average, yet the price barely moved. That strongly suggests: Large buy orders were being absorbed by resting sell liquidity, or Large sell orders were being absorbed by resting buy liquidity This is called absorption, and it’s a hallmark of: Accumulation Distribution Position rotation Market makers managing inventory If this were retail-driven volume, the price would have moved more. 🧱 3. Likely Large Iceberg Orders When you see: High volume Flat price Tight spread …it often means iceberg orders (hidden size) were sitting at key levels. Most likely: 3.40p had a large hidden buyer 3.50p had a large hidden seller This creates a “volume box” where price gets trapped. 🔄 4. Repeated Prints at the Same Price This pattern usually indicates: Market makers refreshing orders Algo participation Institutional accumulation/distribution If you saw lots of trades at 3.45p–3.48p, that’s a sign of: VWAP algos TWAP algos Liquidity-seeking algos These keep the price pinned. 🧭 5. What This Means for Traders This type of order book behaviour usually precedes one of two things: Scenario A — Accumulation If buyers were absorbing sells: Price will break upward once the seller is cleared Volume spike with no drop is bullish Scenario B — Distribution If sellers were absorbing buys: Price will break downward once the buyer is filled Volume spike with no rise is bearish Right now, the book behaviour is neutral-to-accumulative, because: Price did not weaken despite heavy volume No sign of bid collapse No widening spreads That leans slightly bullish. 🎯 Summary Today’s Level 2 behaviour for PRD.L likely showed: Tight spreads Heavy liquidity at 3.40p and 3.50p Iceberg orders absorbing flow Market makers keeping price boxed High volume without directional movement This is classic positioning ahead of news or institutional accumulation.”

data.author: ManWithoutQual
data.content: I'm a long time lurker on this board who has decided to finally jump into the arena. I first invested in PRD after the MOU-2 drill, so while I haven't been involved in PRD as long as some posters, I do have my fair share of scars! I've been accumulating steadily since MOU-2 and have amassed 1.3 million shares. While this may be a pittance compared to others, PRD is my largest single company investment so it matters a great deal to me and I take it seriously. Over the last several years I have been working consistently to gain a better understanding of my investment and I deeply appreciate the knowledgeable contributions of so many posters here. I am neither a financial expert or advisor nor am I an oil and gas expert, I've spent my career building software (including AI before it became the Messiah), but I love to learn and find the whole oil and gas sector utterly fascinating. My interest was first peaked during the shale boom when I was working at a cloud company in Texas and we kicked off a number of discussions with O&G producers about utilizing Permian and Eagle Ford gas to power our data centers. I realize that the sentiment here isn't great after the most recent raise. I confess to have taken it as a gut punch initially. I was expecting the next RNS to be the new ITR and based on the 17 December 2025 "End of Year Operations Update" I was not expecting a placement for any Trinidad operations. But any placing is only dilutive if it's not ultimately accretive. Raising money to engage in operations that have revenue potential is far different from raising money for general corporate purposes. I understand how frustrating delays can be - 2024 and 2025 tried my patience severely - but I am also a student of history, and it strikes me that oil and gas discovery, appraisal, and development is rarely the untrammeled movement from success to success. Pick a field, dig into its history, and you will see that more often than not. Now that I've pontificated enough, I'm onto my question: it seems as though the Jurassic potential is no longer being highlighted despite the fact that there may be untapped potential in other parts of the structure. Instead, the Company is focusing more on the TAGI. Would be interested to hear the opinions of others on the subject. Thanks.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: Sorry Rob. Good find! Found this part interesting! What the placing changes: From a market perspective, the raise alters the near-term picture in several practical ways. Key takeaways post-placing Near-term work programme funded Capital raised ahead of activity, not in response to it Reduced financing overhang during an active operational period Newsflow expected across multiple operations rather than a single event Predator retains 100% ownership of Snowcap-3, maintaining full exposure to any upside The Trinidad programme is sequenced, with multiple wells and workovers planned rather than a one-off Historical flow data combined with improved well placement underpins the Snowcap-3 appraisal rationale Taken together, this shifts the focus from funding uncertainty toward execution. Before any formal appraisal outcome, investors would typically expect a sequence of operational updates rather than a single standalone result. This often includes: Initial drilling update Confirmation of spud Progress toward target depth Early operational observations, where relevant Logging and reservoir evaluation Confirmation that logs have been run Initial indications of reservoir thickness and quality Commentary that is often qualitative rather than fully quantified at first Operational / testing update Flow testing plans or results (if undertaken) Completion status Decisions around tie-in or next operational steps Interesting times ahead !

Before any formal appraisal outcome, investors would typically expect a sequence of operational updates rather than a single standalone result. This often includes: Initial drilling update Confirmation of spud Progress toward target depth Early operational observations, where relevant Logging and reservoir evaluation Confirmation that logs have been run Initial indications of reservoir thickness and quality Commentary that is often qualitative rather than fully quantified at first Operational / testing update Flow testing plans or results (if undertaken) Completion status Decisions around tie-in or next operational steps Interesting times ahead !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I note an increase of filtered posts, so a  reminder of where we are. Trinidad: With the last update, the existing production was 387bopd. Forecasted production is an addition 350/400 bopd. That makes 737/787bopd. That's just the work over the next six to eight weeks by NABI. There will also be revenue from Snowcap 3 shortly. Testing results early Q3. The flow rate is expected to be between 500/1000 bopd, resulting in a revenue, per month, of one/two million. This revenue will not be shared with NABI and is the main reason for the fund raise. The revenue from Snowcap 3 should  quickly recover the placement money. Predator will be using their own T38 refurbished rig. There will then be 2 rigs and teams pushing on with work-overs and new drills! 2000bopd is very doable in the near future. Morocco: We await updated reports and news on negotiations January/February: An updated Independent Technical Resources report ,which will take into consideration the studies completed in 2025, is likely to uplift gas resources for the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure. Validation of the NuTech interpretation of gas saturations is also likely to significantly increase potential for prospective gas resources beyond the limits of the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure in the interval down to 950 metres. A fully-funded Environmental Impact Assessment will be commenced for a CNG/micro-LNG development together with a preliminary Front End Engineering Design concept. Desktop well design and drilling programme will be finalised for an appraisal/development well. The purpose of the fully-funded desktop work during this period is to ensure that the Company and its shareholders get the best possible mutually acceptable terms in commercial negotiations to monetise the discovered gas with the existing entities agreeing to join the Company in a potential FID and development programme. ‌A successful application for an Exploitation Concession in 2026 will crystalise the considerable value currently assigned to the discovered gas in Guercif licence area. Nothing is certain but Predator are moving forward with confidence. There will be a few weeks of churning the placement shares. The unwashed  will do their best to spread panic and fear. However, the reality is: The future is looking really encouraging.with real progress being made on a daily basis.

data.author: OlivettiChamp
data.content: Great response Keith - Very Much Apppreciated! On several occasions I have posted in response to certain individuals accusing me of making stuff up. My responses have then been rapidly removed by lse admin. I can only assume that the same certain people have attached offensive posts to the thread, resulting in the entire thread being removed - this classic troll technique has also been used against other posters here. The claim is then repeated and the cycle continues. A. In response that 'I refuse to admit that MOU-5 was a duster': Why would you put an expensive wellhead on a borehole that has not initially intersected hydrocarbons? Take a look at the top centre seismic chart on p.33 of the October presentation, and it should be obvious. 1). To further investigate the discovery of a Helium concentration of 3120 times the normal background level. 2). To appraise the intersected salt as a potential future gas storage medium, for which a separate ITR has been prepared. 3). To deepen by 1000m to delineate the boundary of the underlying 100kmº anticline of Triassic TAGI sands, which are sealed by a cap of impervious salt. B. With reference to delaying announcement of a commercial discovery in order to maximise tax exemption benefits. 1). It is correct that the standard ONHYM hydrocarbon contract states that the 10-year exemption from corporation tax begins upon commercialisation. However, the situation is more nuanced than this simple statement may seem to imply. I appreciate that nuance may be difficult for some to understand. 2). Upon the declaration of a commercial discovery, an Exploitation Concession must then be applied for within a defined period. This application must include timed and costed proposals to proceed to production. 3). Moroccan Hydrocarbon Code (Law No 21-90 and Decree No 2-93-786) then come into play. The concession can be revoked ("déchéance") for non-compliance, explicitly including "failure to timely complete development works and start operations." 4). It should be obvious that a company or its co-developers would not wish to prematurely announce a commercial discovery until it was in a position to be able to commence large scale production right from day 1, otherwise it would be losing serious amounts of tax benefits on the larger scale production likely in the later years of the exemption period. 5). PRD could have announced a commercial discovery a long time ago. They have not done so, and will not do so, until they have all the ducks in a row. These include * Completed quantification of available gas volumes. * Signed a definitive cooperation and gas sales agreement with an appropriate third party. * Ensured that a fully costed Field Development Plan is agreed. *The financial wherewithal and technical expertise are available to complete such an FDP. 6). The overarching reason for delaying announcement of a commercial discovery is for maximising tax benefits.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: predator oil & gas is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a compressed natural gas (cng) development project in morocco, focusing on the mou-3 well, which has shown potential for gas resources. the company is also preparing for a fully-funded environmental impact assessment for this cng development. energy-pedia.com **********.com overview of predator oil & gas in morocco predator oil & gas holdings is actively involved in the development of gas resources in morocco, particularly focusing on the guercif region. the company is working on a potential compressed natural gas (cng) project, which aims to monetize discovered gas reserves. current developments gas appraisal and development predator is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a final investment decision (fid) regarding gas appraisal and development. the mou-3 well has been identified as a key site for initial appraisal and potential development, focusing on the section above 950 meters. cng project plans discussions are ongoing with two parties for a fully-funded cng and/or micro-lng development. a fully-funded environmental impact assessment is set to commence for the cng/micro-lng development, along with preliminary engineering design concepts. financial position predator is fully funded to meet its commitments for the next twelve months, allowing it to accelerate its transition to production. the company has reported significant gas resources in the mou-1 and mou-3 wells, with estimates suggesting a potential standalone cng development project. future outlook the company aims to increase its production capacity and revenue through the successful implementation of its cng plans. the ongoing studies and testing are expected to enhance the understanding of gas saturations and improve the potential for gas resources in the region.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: Predator has an interesting gas project in Morocco with fast pace of commercialisation and significant upside. The Guercif project is a shallow CNG biogenic gas development with different traps and separate identified reservoirs. The Jurassic Titanosaurus is a shallow thermogenic gas prospect evaluating 249m of potential gross reservoir thickness in a trap of maximum closure of 187 km2 for pipeline gas to power, with pipeline 2.5km from wellhead. Moroccan gas prices are high, and the fiscal terms are some of the best in the world. Predator also has a diversified portfolio of assets across Ireland and Trinidad, which is a near-term revenue-generating project Let’s hope for some upward momentum very soon 🚀

"Europa Oil & Gas (Holdings) plc, the AIM quoted West Africa, UK, and Ireland and focused oil and gas exploration, development and production company, is pleased to announce that it has received confirmation from the Irish Government's Department of Climate, Energy  and the Environment that, whilst the FEL 4/19 licence Phase 1 extension application is under consideration, it remains live and in Phase 1 until the application process is concluded. Will Holland, Chief Executive Officer of Europa, said: "FEL 4/19 contains the large 1.5 TCF, low risk Inishkea West gas prospect and is a strategic asset that can potentially provide a reliable source of low emission energy for Ireland and play a key role in the transition to renewable green power. data.content: Hey, Keith. Had a little look into hyperspectural satellites for hydrocarbons. I am so glad you are here to put many things in to small bite, layman’s terms. My head hurts Reading such as…. The radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction and orthorectification were done on ENVI + IDL (version 5.3) software (Harris Geospatial Solutions, Inc., Broomfield, CO, USA). The stripe noise removal was carried out by the full image stripe noise removal method (Tan et al., Citation2005). The calculation formula of this method is 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘=𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘+𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 /𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 −𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑚𝑘 , ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑠𝑘 where 𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the radiation value of the i column and j line in the K band; 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the corrected radiation value; the 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column; 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, i column; ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column of the reference image; ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, the i column of the reference image. The 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘 is the sensor gain and the 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 is the offset; ¯ 𝑚𝑘 is the mean value of the whole image in the K band; ¯ In plain English, Will  I be rich one day? 🤔 𝑠𝑘 is the mean standard deviation of the whole image in the K band.

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 2. Hyperspectral satellite data (which I have not seen, but I trust the interpretation I have been given) shows abundant gas underground in the whole area.  This data cannot indicate the depth of the gas source, so even were there no actual gas in the Jurassic, this suggests that the underlying Triassic is gas-charged. Across N. Africa, the TAGI is one of the most prolific sources of hydrocarbons.  It was known (from the above work by PG) to be at Tendrara.  Here the main TAGI is at a depth of 2600 – 2800m.  Well TE-6 shows 28m net of reservoir, TE-10 has 10m net, 110m gross.  TE-7 & TE-8 show hundreds of metres gross depth.  The problem is that at Tendrara the reservoir quality is poor, with 8% porosity, as opposed to up to 15% elsewhere.  This requires mechanical stimulation (fracking / acidizing) for commercial flow.  Interestingly, the same satellite data referred to above was ignored by SOU's James Parsons, resulting in the Tendrara drills being sub-optimally positioned. From what I can tell from the limited seismic data publicly available, the top of the Guercif Triassic is about 1000m closer to the surface than at Tendrara.  This will not only be cheaper to drill, but also likely to be less compacted, resulting in improved reservoir quality.  PG is probably the best qualified person on Earth to make that call, but I assume he has weighed up the cost : benefit potential for large, well sealed Triassic reservoirs as opposed to complex Jurassic structures, hence the change in near-term strategy. "When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?" John Maynard Keynes.
data.thread_title: RE: Why the new emphasis on the Triassic?

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 1. @MwoQ.  Great to see a new contributor, especially one asking an interesting question that I'm sure others have also wondered about. The view has been expressed on here by the usual suspects that there is no gas in the Jurassic, so 'bait & switch' has moved attention somewhere else, in this case the Triassic.  I don't agree with that, although of course what follows is my own personal interpretation. Paul Griffiths has a vastly more comprehensive view of these matters – after his MSc on 'Late Mesozoic seismic sequence stratigraphy of NE Libya' he worked for the Libyan National Oil Company and Gulf Oil evaluating exactly the potential reservoirs PRD are working on today.  Later in his career he worked up the initial evaluation of the TAGI opportunity at Tendrara, 125km south of Guercif, which will be producing for Sound / Mana later this year. First, we need to understand the complexity of the Jurassic carbonate.  The Titanosaurus structure is basically a huge fossil coral reef, laid down in waters of varying depth over millions of years.  When the water was deep, sediment would mostly be fine-grained, resulting in dense rock with poor hydrocarbon reservoir potential.  In shallow water, coral reef proper would form, and this rock, already of sponge-like texture, would be further eroded by periodic exposure to the air and/or waves.  This exposure results in leached porosity development - which means what it says – increased pores and cavities resulting in excellent capacity as a hydrocarbon reservoir.  From this, it can be seen there will be vertically stacked high potential reservoirs alternating with non-productive strata.  Added to this complexity is the likelihood of horizontal variation – think of many reefs separated by infilled channels. Directly beneath the Jurassic is the top of the Triassic – marked by a thick layer of salt resulting from the evaporation of part of the ancient Tethys Sea, of which the Med forms a small remnant.  This salt acts as a very viscous liquid, moving upwards and sideways due to the pressure of overlying rock. This layer is impervious to gas, so forms an excellent seal for any gas reservoirs beneath.  However, the seismic wave conduction velocities of rock salt and carbonate reservoir are very similar, making them difficult to distinguish. The seismic data available to PRD is not that great, tbh. As a result, MOU-5 was drilled into a laterally mobilised salt layer, not carbonate reservoir.  It seems that the particular part of Titanosaurus that was drilled has been isolated from gas migration by salt above, below and laterally.  Correlation of drilled material with the seismic data has resulted in a greatly improved understanding of the structure.  There is every possibility that the structure contains multiple TCF of gas, but will require more detailed geophysical evaluation, which will cost more than PRD can afford – hence the farm in process currently underway.

data.author: JoshW7
data.content: Welcome to the board ManWithoutQual. Rather like you I'm no O&G expert either, my take on your question is Predator’s recent messaging emphasises the TAGI reservoirs rather than the Jurassic, not because the Jurassic has lost value but because TAGI offers a faster, lower‑risk route to commercial gas. TAGI wells are shallower and cheaper to drill. The Jurassic remains a large, high‑impact target, but drilling it requires more capital, deeper wells, and potentially a partner. By proving TAGI commerciality first, Predator strengthens its negotiating position and de‑risks the basin. The shift is strategic sequencing: TAGI now, Jurassic later as the transformational upside. I'm sure others will chip in with their take on it too but that's my starter for 10.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: I did find this from TW’s  copilot: “Here’s a clear, trader‑level breakdown of what the order book was almost certainly doing today. 📘 Level 2 Behaviour Assessment for PRD.L (Today) 🧩 1. Tight Spread = Balanced Book PRD.L traded in a very narrow range (3.40p–3.50p) with the mid-price barely moving. A tight spread like that usually means: Market makers were well-supplied on both sides No aggressive buyers lifting the ask No aggressive sellers hitting the bid This is classic neutral order book behaviour. 📈 2. High Volume, No Price Movement = Absorption Volume was 3× the daily average, yet the price barely moved. That strongly suggests: Large buy orders were being absorbed by resting sell liquidity, or Large sell orders were being absorbed by resting buy liquidity This is called absorption, and it’s a hallmark of: Accumulation Distribution Position rotation Market makers managing inventory If this were retail-driven volume, the price would have moved more. 🧱 3. Likely Large Iceberg Orders When you see: High volume Flat price Tight spread …it often means iceberg orders (hidden size) were sitting at key levels. Most likely: 3.40p had a large hidden buyer 3.50p had a large hidden seller This creates a “volume box” where price gets trapped. 🔄 4. Repeated Prints at the Same Price This pattern usually indicates: Market makers refreshing orders Algo participation Institutional accumulation/distribution If you saw lots of trades at 3.45p–3.48p, that’s a sign of: VWAP algos TWAP algos Liquidity-seeking algos These keep the price pinned. 🧭 5. What This Means for Traders This type of order book behaviour usually precedes one of two things: Scenario A — Accumulation If buyers were absorbing sells: Price will break upward once the seller is cleared Volume spike with no drop is bullish Scenario B — Distribution If sellers were absorbing buys: Price will break downward once the buyer is filled Volume spike with no rise is bearish Right now, the book behaviour is neutral-to-accumulative, because: Price did not weaken despite heavy volume No sign of bid collapse No widening spreads That leans slightly bullish. 🎯 Summary Today’s Level 2 behaviour for PRD.L likely showed: Tight spreads Heavy liquidity at 3.40p and 3.50p Iceberg orders absorbing flow Market makers keeping price boxed High volume without directional movement This is classic positioning ahead of news or institutional accumulation.”
