data.author: ManWithoutQual
data.content: I'm a long time lurker on this board who has decided to finally jump into the arena. I first invested in PRD after the MOU-2 drill, so while I haven't been involved in PRD as long as some posters, I do have my fair share of scars! I've been accumulating steadily since MOU-2 and have amassed 1.3 million shares. While this may be a pittance compared to others, PRD is my largest single company investment so it matters a great deal to me and I take it seriously. Over the last several years I have been working consistently to gain a better understanding of my investment and I deeply appreciate the knowledgeable contributions of so many posters here. I am neither a financial expert or advisor nor am I an oil and gas expert, I've spent my career building software (including AI before it became the Messiah), but I love to learn and find the whole oil and gas sector utterly fascinating. My interest was first peaked during the shale boom when I was working at a cloud company in Texas and we kicked off a number of discussions with O&G producers about utilizing Permian and Eagle Ford gas to power our data centers. I realize that the sentiment here isn't great after the most recent raise. I confess to have taken it as a gut punch initially. I was expecting the next RNS to be the new ITR and based on the 17 December 2025 "End of Year Operations Update" I was not expecting a placement for any Trinidad operations. But any placing is only dilutive if it's not ultimately accretive. Raising money to engage in operations that have revenue potential is far different from raising money for general corporate purposes. I understand how frustrating delays can be - 2024 and 2025 tried my patience severely - but I am also a student of history, and it strikes me that oil and gas discovery, appraisal, and development is rarely the untrammeled movement from success to success. Pick a field, dig into its history, and you will see that more often than not. Now that I've pontificated enough, I'm onto my question: it seems as though the Jurassic potential is no longer being highlighted despite the fact that there may be untapped potential in other parts of the structure. Instead, the Company is focusing more on the TAGI. Would be interested to hear the opinions of others on the subject. Thanks.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: Sorry Rob. Good find! Found this part interesting! What the placing changes: From a market perspective, the raise alters the near-term picture in several practical ways. Key takeaways post-placing Near-term work programme funded Capital raised ahead of activity, not in response to it Reduced financing overhang during an active operational period Newsflow expected across multiple operations rather than a single event Predator retains 100% ownership of Snowcap-3, maintaining full exposure to any upside The Trinidad programme is sequenced, with multiple wells and workovers planned rather than a one-off Historical flow data combined with improved well placement underpins the Snowcap-3 appraisal rationale Taken together, this shifts the focus from funding uncertainty toward execution. Before any formal appraisal outcome, investors would typically expect a sequence of operational updates rather than a single standalone result. This often includes: Initial drilling update Confirmation of spud Progress toward target depth Early operational observations, where relevant Logging and reservoir evaluation Confirmation that logs have been run Initial indications of reservoir thickness and quality Commentary that is often qualitative rather than fully quantified at first Operational / testing update Flow testing plans or results (if undertaken) Completion status Decisions around tie-in or next operational steps Interesting times ahead !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I note an increase of filtered posts, so a  reminder of where we are. Trinidad: With the last update, the existing production was 387bopd. Forecasted production is an addition 350/400 bopd. That makes 737/787bopd. That's just the work over the next six to eight weeks by NABI. There will also be revenue from Snowcap 3 shortly. Testing results early Q3. The flow rate is expected to be between 500/1000 bopd, resulting in a revenue, per month, of one/two million. This revenue will not be shared with NABI and is the main reason for the fund raise. The revenue from Snowcap 3 should  quickly recover the placement money. Predator will be using their own T38 refurbished rig. There will then be 2 rigs and teams pushing on with work-overs and new drills! 2000bopd is very doable in the near future. Morocco: We await updated reports and news on negotiations January/February: An updated Independent Technical Resources report ,which will take into consideration the studies completed in 2025, is likely to uplift gas resources for the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure. Validation of the NuTech interpretation of gas saturations is also likely to significantly increase potential for prospective gas resources beyond the limits of the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure in the interval down to 950 metres. A fully-funded Environmental Impact Assessment will be commenced for a CNG/micro-LNG development together with a preliminary Front End Engineering Design concept. Desktop well design and drilling programme will be finalised for an appraisal/development well. The purpose of the fully-funded desktop work during this period is to ensure that the Company and its shareholders get the best possible mutually acceptable terms in commercial negotiations to monetise the discovered gas with the existing entities agreeing to join the Company in a potential FID and development programme. ‌A successful application for an Exploitation Concession in 2026 will crystalise the considerable value currently assigned to the discovered gas in Guercif licence area. Nothing is certain but Predator are moving forward with confidence. There will be a few weeks of churning the placement shares. The unwashed  will do their best to spread panic and fear. However, the reality is: The future is looking really encouraging.with real progress being made on a daily basis.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Thank you pv72,  your valuation gives us a great indication of how important Trinidad is. If we were to achieve the higher production of 1000bopd on SC-3 the revised figures would be: 1. NABI gets to 1000bopd, and we get 15% 2. SC-3  produced 1000bopd 3. We produce oil only for 300 days pa to allow for extended outages 4. Price per barrel at only $55 usd 5. PER at 10 6. $1.3=£1 1150x300x55x10÷1.3 gives us £146m market cap which gives us a top end of  17.9p per share in a success case. So a possable 10/20 p valuation is not too far off by Q4. These figures shows why PG decided to go down the placement route. If all goes well, this year, then Trinidad should drive up the value (Fingers crossed) What then? Continue to increase production? Increase production equals increase share price....... Or.... Sell? Until SC-3 is drilled and tested we can only hope that the production will be successful. It's easy to get carried away and patience is required. But.... The figures look good, NABI are ahead of Predator's target of the end of the year. Snowcap 2 and 3 are in proven regions. Interesting times ahead.

data.author: Gudin
data.content: PRD does not get 30%, that goes to Steeldrum which is split 51% PRD/ 49% WIEGL. The rns on January 21st 2025 clearly states they bought a 51% stake in CRL whose only asset was the bonasse field and there has been no further purchase of the remaining 49% released in an rns. The rns on 21st September 2025 clearly states the Goudron, Inniss trinity and Icacos holding companies would be transferred into  CRL which was renamed Steeldrum. In exchange for this 49% of the three CEG fields the 49% partner in Steeldrum WIEGL have taken on the $4.25m of liabilities from the CEG fields. PRD will be receiving 7.5% of production from bonasse, Goudron, Inniss trinity and Icacos fields until Nabi recover the costs , then they will revert to 15%. So if Nabi hit 1000bpd PRD will be receiving 7.5% of the 700 bpd increase which is 53bpd until costs are recovered and raising to 105 bpd when this had occurred.  Just for comparison PRD paid £2m for 282bpd of production to CEG, so valuations of ten times this for lower production is a bold claim. Even if the full 1000bpd is split between the two holders of Steeldrum then PRD will have 510 bpd  which is not quite twice the production they paid £2m for.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I fully expect NABI to achieve an oil production level of 1000 bopd later in the year. Predator receives 30% of gross sales revenues from existing production less taxes and royalties and 15% of new production until recovery of NABI costs, thereafter 30% of net sales revenues. We also have Snowcap  3 in the pipeline. This well has the potential to add 500/1000 bopd and unlike the NABI drills, this drill is financed by Predator with Predator keeping the profits. We will also be working on Snowcap 1. I'm not sure what we are expecting there. The current share price  is due to the placement price of 3.5p, with the MM's keeping it low to achieve maximum profit. Like all placement churns it will pass. I'm looking forward to receiving various RNS's, informing us of progress. The news, if positive, will add to the value. My personal opinion is that the NABI's production on its own would underpin the current share value, once the 1000 bopd target is achieved. Trinidad is an ongoing operation with multiple work overs still to undertake this year and next year? What  would the NABI work-over's and a successful SC-3 add to our share price? Is 10/20p a realistic figure? Obviously, it will depend on an successful SC-3. Just my take and I'd appreciate other posters's valuations and views. It does make today's price rather attract and may explain the troll activities at the weekend. We all like low buy-in prices! We also have news on Morocco to come.

If they feel betrayed by the company, they may be airing their grievances out of disappointment. • Competitive Bias – They hold stock in another company and genuinely believe their company is superior and see the competitor as a threat. • Personal or Professional Ties – They have direct involvement with another company, leading to bias against the competitor.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Morocco: MOU-6 well planning near finalisation. Mou-1: Formation gas shows were recorded in a shallow sand at 605 metres measured depth ("MD") comprising 2.35% or 19,392 ppm C1 methane. Total background, exclusively dry gas, increased from 0.6% to 1.7% (5,232 to 13,800 ppm C1) down to 1,159 metres MD. Formation gas shows of 1.8% and 3.8% (13,355 to 36,035 ppm C1) were encountered whilst drilling this section. Below 1,159 metres in the lower Guebbas and Hoot (using the stratigraphic nomenclature of the Rharb Basin) total background gas was from 0.7% to 1.5% (5,000 to 11,996 ppm C1) but with traces of heavier gases C2, C3 and C4. Formation gas shows of up to 1.67% (13,643 ppm total gases) were also recorded. Wireline logs were run from 724 to 1487.4 metres MD over the interval with gas shows. MOU-2 was drilled to 1,260 metres Measured Depth before being suspended for operational reasons for a possible later re-entry. THREE GAS samples collected whilst drilling. 100 metres of variable quality sand in primary target. MOU-3 was drilled to 1,509 metres Measured Depth and completed for rigless testing. SEVEN GAS samples collected whilst drilling. 50.5 metres of gross sand interval in primary target. Secondary targets Ma and TGB-6 sand intervals confirmed to be present and GAS- based on NuTech petrophysics and GAS samples collected whilst drilling. Ma and TGB-6 intervals correlated with MOU-1 drilled in 2021 to potentially define a single structure covering up to 21 km2. 11 metres of unexpected sand encountered at shallow depth with OVER-PRESSURISED GAS. Formation damage predicted due to necessity to drill with heavy drilling mud - to be potentially penetrated using Sandjet rigless testing technology. · MOU-4 was drilled to 1,199 metres Measured Depth and completed for rigless testing. Unexpected 58 metres of gross M1 Sand potential reservoir interval, interpreted by NuTech as GAS-BEARING . 21 metres of gross sand in primary target with improved reservoir characteristics compared to MOU-3 and interpreted as GAS-BEARING by NuTech petrophysics. I'm looking forward to the ITR... Trinidad update soon !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Great post Keith ! The trolls are trying hard to fill this BB with FUD. Factual post like this harm the trolls agenda. They are unable to to analyse your post and respond with ignorance. ONHYM do not award licences. ONHYM and the company agree the terms necessary to award a licence. This was completed last year. The licence is awarded by the Energy Ministry, after sign off by the Finance Ministry. This is a contractual obligation. I am not aware of a single situation where ONHYM, or their predecessor ONAREP, has agreed licence terms then a licence is not issued. If you know of such an instance, please reference it. I have never said that a declaration of commerciality is up to Paul Griffiths “to make by himself “, so please do not distort my statements. I have made it crystal clear what specific events need to occur and be agreed before such declaration can be made – these constitute 3 of the 4 bullet points in my first post this morning, including commercial gas flow, a gas sales agreement and an FDP. So why suggest that I have not stated this when I have? I repeat, PG does have significant say on WHEN such declaration is made, and yes, the timing is driven by tax issues. Dr Tim Wright, FGS, FSEG, MIMMM of Scorpion Geosciences is an accredited Competent Person, meaning that he is deemed fully qualified and has direct personal experience of the necessary geological, geophysical and geotechnical aspects of this project. He is well known within the industry. It is a requirement that he has full and free access to whatever data has been generated. There is a lot of data. This same data will have been supplied to all companies and organisations (including ONHYM) for review by their own technical experts. I cannot possibly imagine that any credible potential partner would sign an agreement without doing their own very detailed Due Diligence. If there were to be significant discrepancies in their interpretation of the data compared to Scorpion's, that would be resolved by further discussion. Please detail the qualifications and experience that you have that put you in a reasonable position to question the veracity of past and forthcoming ITRs. I repeat that I had absolutely nothing to do with any 'Research Report' posted on this bulletin board. Anything I post is my own opinion, under my own name, based on publicly available information, which I usually reference. Potential investors should always check the facts behind any statement here. Please note that the Company has made it very clear that information on social media can be inadvertently or even deliberately misleading, and urged investors to rely only on statements in an RNS and the Company's official X account. I don't expect an apology - but if I said why I don't expect an apology, it would indeed be an insult, albeit a deserved one.

data.author: OlivettiChamp
data.content: Great response Keith - Very Much Apppreciated! On several occasions I have posted in response to certain individuals accusing me of making stuff up. My responses have then been rapidly removed by lse admin. I can only assume that the same certain people have attached offensive posts to the thread, resulting in the entire thread being removed - this classic troll technique has also been used against other posters here. The claim is then repeated and the cycle continues. A. In response that 'I refuse to admit that MOU-5 was a duster': Why would you put an expensive wellhead on a borehole that has not initially intersected hydrocarbons? Take a look at the top centre seismic chart on p.33 of the October presentation, and it should be obvious. 1). To further investigate the discovery of a Helium concentration of 3120 times the normal background level. 2). To appraise the intersected salt as a potential future gas storage medium, for which a separate ITR has been prepared. 3). To deepen by 1000m to delineate the boundary of the underlying 100kmº anticline of Triassic TAGI sands, which are sealed by a cap of impervious salt. B. With reference to delaying announcement of a commercial discovery in order to maximise tax exemption benefits. 1). It is correct that the standard ONHYM hydrocarbon contract states that the 10-year exemption from corporation tax begins upon commercialisation. However, the situation is more nuanced than this simple statement may seem to imply. I appreciate that nuance may be difficult for some to understand. 2). Upon the declaration of a commercial discovery, an Exploitation Concession must then be applied for within a defined period. This application must include timed and costed proposals to proceed to production. 3). Moroccan Hydrocarbon Code (Law No 21-90 and Decree No 2-93-786) then come into play. The concession can be revoked ("déchéance") for non-compliance, explicitly including "failure to timely complete development works and start operations." 4). It should be obvious that a company or its co-developers would not wish to prematurely announce a commercial discovery until it was in a position to be able to commence large scale production right from day 1, otherwise it would be losing serious amounts of tax benefits on the larger scale production likely in the later years of the exemption period. 5). PRD could have announced a commercial discovery a long time ago. They have not done so, and will not do so, until they have all the ducks in a row. These include * Completed quantification of available gas volumes. * Signed a definitive cooperation and gas sales agreement with an appropriate third party. * Ensured that a fully costed Field Development Plan is agreed. *The financial wherewithal and technical expertise are available to complete such an FDP. 6). The overarching reason for delaying announcement of a commercial discovery is for maximising tax benefits.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: predator oil & gas is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a compressed natural gas (cng) development project in morocco, focusing on the mou-3 well, which has shown potential for gas resources. the company is also preparing for a fully-funded environmental impact assessment for this cng development. energy-pedia.com **********.com overview of predator oil & gas in morocco predator oil & gas holdings is actively involved in the development of gas resources in morocco, particularly focusing on the guercif region. the company is working on a potential compressed natural gas (cng) project, which aims to monetize discovered gas reserves. current developments gas appraisal and development predator is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a final investment decision (fid) regarding gas appraisal and development. the mou-3 well has been identified as a key site for initial appraisal and potential development, focusing on the section above 950 meters. cng project plans discussions are ongoing with two parties for a fully-funded cng and/or micro-lng development. a fully-funded environmental impact assessment is set to commence for the cng/micro-lng development, along with preliminary engineering design concepts. financial position predator is fully funded to meet its commitments for the next twelve months, allowing it to accelerate its transition to production. the company has reported significant gas resources in the mou-1 and mou-3 wells, with estimates suggesting a potential standalone cng development project. future outlook the company aims to increase its production capacity and revenue through the successful implementation of its cng plans. the ongoing studies and testing are expected to enhance the understanding of gas saturations and improve the potential for gas resources in the region.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: Predator has an interesting gas project in Morocco with fast pace of commercialisation and significant upside. The Guercif project is a shallow CNG biogenic gas development with different traps and separate identified reservoirs. The Jurassic Titanosaurus is a shallow thermogenic gas prospect evaluating 249m of potential gross reservoir thickness in a trap of maximum closure of 187 km2 for pipeline gas to power, with pipeline 2.5km from wellhead. Moroccan gas prices are high, and the fiscal terms are some of the best in the world. Predator also has a diversified portfolio of assets across Ireland and Trinidad, which is a near-term revenue-generating project Let’s hope for some upward momentum very soon 🚀

data.content: Hey, Keith. Had a little look into hyperspectural satellites for hydrocarbons. I am so glad you are here to put many things in to small bite, layman’s terms. My head hurts Reading such as…. The radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction and orthorectification were done on ENVI + IDL (version 5.3) software (Harris Geospatial Solutions, Inc., Broomfield, CO, USA). The stripe noise removal was carried out by the full image stripe noise removal method (Tan et al., Citation2005). The calculation formula of this method is 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘=𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘+𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 /𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 −𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑚𝑘 , ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑠𝑘 where 𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the radiation value of the i column and j line in the K band; 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the corrected radiation value; the 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column; 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, i column; ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column of the reference image; ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, the i column of the reference image. The 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘 is the sensor gain and the 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 is the offset; ¯ 𝑚𝑘 is the mean value of the whole image in the K band; ¯ In plain English, Will  I be rich one day? 🤔 𝑠𝑘 is the mean standard deviation of the whole image in the K band.

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 2. Hyperspectral satellite data (which I have not seen, but I trust the interpretation I have been given) shows abundant gas underground in the whole area.  This data cannot indicate the depth of the gas source, so even were there no actual gas in the Jurassic, this suggests that the underlying Triassic is gas-charged. Across N. Africa, the TAGI is one of the most prolific sources of hydrocarbons.  It was known (from the above work by PG) to be at Tendrara.  Here the main TAGI is at a depth of 2600 – 2800m.  Well TE-6 shows 28m net of reservoir, TE-10 has 10m net, 110m gross.  TE-7 & TE-8 show hundreds of metres gross depth.  The problem is that at Tendrara the reservoir quality is poor, with 8% porosity, as opposed to up to 15% elsewhere.  This requires mechanical stimulation (fracking / acidizing) for commercial flow.  Interestingly, the same satellite data referred to above was ignored by SOU's James Parsons, resulting in the Tendrara drills being sub-optimally positioned. From what I can tell from the limited seismic data publicly available, the top of the Guercif Triassic is about 1000m closer to the surface than at Tendrara.  This will not only be cheaper to drill, but also likely to be less compacted, resulting in improved reservoir quality.  PG is probably the best qualified person on Earth to make that call, but I assume he has weighed up the cost : benefit potential for large, well sealed Triassic reservoirs as opposed to complex Jurassic structures, hence the change in near-term strategy. "When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?" John Maynard Keynes.
data.thread_title: RE: Why the new emphasis on the Triassic?

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 1. @MwoQ.  Great to see a new contributor, especially one asking an interesting question that I'm sure others have also wondered about. The view has been expressed on here by the usual suspects that there is no gas in the Jurassic, so 'bait & switch' has moved attention somewhere else, in this case the Triassic.  I don't agree with that, although of course what follows is my own personal interpretation. Paul Griffiths has a vastly more comprehensive view of these matters – after his MSc on 'Late Mesozoic seismic sequence stratigraphy of NE Libya' he worked for the Libyan National Oil Company and Gulf Oil evaluating exactly the potential reservoirs PRD are working on today.  Later in his career he worked up the initial evaluation of the TAGI opportunity at Tendrara, 125km south of Guercif, which will be producing for Sound / Mana later this year. First, we need to understand the complexity of the Jurassic carbonate.  The Titanosaurus structure is basically a huge fossil coral reef, laid down in waters of varying depth over millions of years.  When the water was deep, sediment would mostly be fine-grained, resulting in dense rock with poor hydrocarbon reservoir potential.  In shallow water, coral reef proper would form, and this rock, already of sponge-like texture, would be further eroded by periodic exposure to the air and/or waves.  This exposure results in leached porosity development - which means what it says – increased pores and cavities resulting in excellent capacity as a hydrocarbon reservoir.  From this, it can be seen there will be vertically stacked high potential reservoirs alternating with non-productive strata.  Added to this complexity is the likelihood of horizontal variation – think of many reefs separated by infilled channels. Directly beneath the Jurassic is the top of the Triassic – marked by a thick layer of salt resulting from the evaporation of part of the ancient Tethys Sea, of which the Med forms a small remnant.  This salt acts as a very viscous liquid, moving upwards and sideways due to the pressure of overlying rock. This layer is impervious to gas, so forms an excellent seal for any gas reservoirs beneath.  However, the seismic wave conduction velocities of rock salt and carbonate reservoir are very similar, making them difficult to distinguish. The seismic data available to PRD is not that great, tbh. As a result, MOU-5 was drilled into a laterally mobilised salt layer, not carbonate reservoir.  It seems that the particular part of Titanosaurus that was drilled has been isolated from gas migration by salt above, below and laterally.  Correlation of drilled material with the seismic data has resulted in a greatly improved understanding of the structure.  There is every possibility that the structure contains multiple TCF of gas, but will require more detailed geophysical evaluation, which will cost more than PRD can afford – hence the farm in process currently underway.

data.author: JoshW7
data.content: Welcome to the board ManWithoutQual. Rather like you I'm no O&G expert either, my take on your question is Predator’s recent messaging emphasises the TAGI reservoirs rather than the Jurassic, not because the Jurassic has lost value but because TAGI offers a faster, lower‑risk route to commercial gas. TAGI wells are shallower and cheaper to drill. The Jurassic remains a large, high‑impact target, but drilling it requires more capital, deeper wells, and potentially a partner. By proving TAGI commerciality first, Predator strengthens its negotiating position and de‑risks the basin. The shift is strategic sequencing: TAGI now, Jurassic later as the transformational upside. I'm sure others will chip in with their take on it too but that's my starter for 10.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: I did find this from TW’s  copilot: “Here’s a clear, trader‑level breakdown of what the order book was almost certainly doing today. 📘 Level 2 Behaviour Assessment for PRD.L (Today) 🧩 1. Tight Spread = Balanced Book PRD.L traded in a very narrow range (3.40p–3.50p) with the mid-price barely moving. A tight spread like that usually means: Market makers were well-supplied on both sides No aggressive buyers lifting the ask No aggressive sellers hitting the bid This is classic neutral order book behaviour. 📈 2. High Volume, No Price Movement = Absorption Volume was 3× the daily average, yet the price barely moved. That strongly suggests: Large buy orders were being absorbed by resting sell liquidity, or Large sell orders were being absorbed by resting buy liquidity This is called absorption, and it’s a hallmark of: Accumulation Distribution Position rotation Market makers managing inventory If this were retail-driven volume, the price would have moved more. 🧱 3. Likely Large Iceberg Orders When you see: High volume Flat price Tight spread …it often means iceberg orders (hidden size) were sitting at key levels. Most likely: 3.40p had a large hidden buyer 3.50p had a large hidden seller This creates a “volume box” where price gets trapped. 🔄 4. Repeated Prints at the Same Price This pattern usually indicates: Market makers refreshing orders Algo participation Institutional accumulation/distribution If you saw lots of trades at 3.45p–3.48p, that’s a sign of: VWAP algos TWAP algos Liquidity-seeking algos These keep the price pinned. 🧭 5. What This Means for Traders This type of order book behaviour usually precedes one of two things: Scenario A — Accumulation If buyers were absorbing sells: Price will break upward once the seller is cleared Volume spike with no drop is bullish Scenario B — Distribution If sellers were absorbing buys: Price will break downward once the buyer is filled Volume spike with no rise is bearish Right now, the book behaviour is neutral-to-accumulative, because: Price did not weaken despite heavy volume No sign of bid collapse No widening spreads That leans slightly bullish. 🎯 Summary Today’s Level 2 behaviour for PRD.L likely showed: Tight spreads Heavy liquidity at 3.40p and 3.50p Iceberg orders absorbing flow Market makers keeping price boxed High volume without directional movement This is classic positioning ahead of news or institutional accumulation.”

data.author: ManWithoutQual
data.content: I'm a long time lurker on this board who has decided to finally jump into the arena. I first invested in PRD after the MOU-2 drill, so while I haven't been involved in PRD as long as some posters, I do have my fair share of scars! I've been accumulating steadily since MOU-2 and have amassed 1.3 million shares. While this may be a pittance compared to others, PRD is my largest single company investment so it matters a great deal to me and I take it seriously. Over the last several years I have been working consistently to gain a better understanding of my investment and I deeply appreciate the knowledgeable contributions of so many posters here. I am neither a financial expert or advisor nor am I an oil and gas expert, I've spent my career building software (including AI before it became the Messiah), but I love to learn and find the whole oil and gas sector utterly fascinating. My interest was first peaked during the shale boom when I was working at a cloud company in Texas and we kicked off a number of discussions with O&G producers about utilizing Permian and Eagle Ford gas to power our data centers. I realize that the sentiment here isn't great after the most recent raise. I confess to have taken it as a gut punch initially. I was expecting the next RNS to be the new ITR and based on the 17 December 2025 "End of Year Operations Update" I was not expecting a placement for any Trinidad operations. But any placing is only dilutive if it's not ultimately accretive. Raising money to engage in operations that have revenue potential is far different from raising money for general corporate purposes. I understand how frustrating delays can be - 2024 and 2025 tried my patience severely - but I am also a student of history, and it strikes me that oil and gas discovery, appraisal, and development is rarely the untrammeled movement from success to success. Pick a field, dig into its history, and you will see that more often than not. Now that I've pontificated enough, I'm onto my question: it seems as though the Jurassic potential is no longer being highlighted despite the fact that there may be untapped potential in other parts of the structure. Instead, the Company is focusing more on the TAGI. Would be interested to hear the opinions of others on the subject. Thanks.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: Sorry Rob. Good find! Found this part interesting! What the placing changes: From a market perspective, the raise alters the near-term picture in several practical ways. Key takeaways post-placing Near-term work programme funded Capital raised ahead of activity, not in response to it Reduced financing overhang during an active operational period Newsflow expected across multiple operations rather than a single event Predator retains 100% ownership of Snowcap-3, maintaining full exposure to any upside The Trinidad programme is sequenced, with multiple wells and workovers planned rather than a one-off Historical flow data combined with improved well placement underpins the Snowcap-3 appraisal rationale Taken together, this shifts the focus from funding uncertainty toward execution. Before any formal appraisal outcome, investors would typically expect a sequence of operational updates rather than a single standalone result. This often includes: Initial drilling update Confirmation of spud Progress toward target depth Early operational observations, where relevant Logging and reservoir evaluation Confirmation that logs have been run Initial indications of reservoir thickness and quality Commentary that is often qualitative rather than fully quantified at first Operational / testing update Flow testing plans or results (if undertaken) Completion status Decisions around tie-in or next operational steps Interesting times ahead !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I note an increase of filtered posts, so a  reminder of where we are. Trinidad: With the last update, the existing production was 387bopd. Forecasted production is an addition 350/400 bopd. That makes 737/787bopd. That's just the work over the next six to eight weeks by NABI. There will also be revenue from Snowcap 3 shortly. Testing results early Q3. The flow rate is expected to be between 500/1000 bopd, resulting in a revenue, per month, of one/two million. This revenue will not be shared with NABI and is the main reason for the fund raise. The revenue from Snowcap 3 should  quickly recover the placement money. Predator will be using their own T38 refurbished rig. There will then be 2 rigs and teams pushing on with work-overs and new drills! 2000bopd is very doable in the near future. Morocco: We await updated reports and news on negotiations January/February: An updated Independent Technical Resources report ,which will take into consideration the studies completed in 2025, is likely to uplift gas resources for the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure. Validation of the NuTech interpretation of gas saturations is also likely to significantly increase potential for prospective gas resources beyond the limits of the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure in the interval down to 950 metres. A fully-funded Environmental Impact Assessment will be commenced for a CNG/micro-LNG development together with a preliminary Front End Engineering Design concept. Desktop well design and drilling programme will be finalised for an appraisal/development well. The purpose of the fully-funded desktop work during this period is to ensure that the Company and its shareholders get the best possible mutually acceptable terms in commercial negotiations to monetise the discovered gas with the existing entities agreeing to join the Company in a potential FID and development programme. ‌A successful application for an Exploitation Concession in 2026 will crystalise the considerable value currently assigned to the discovered gas in Guercif licence area. Nothing is certain but Predator are moving forward with confidence. There will be a few weeks of churning the placement shares. The unwashed  will do their best to spread panic and fear. However, the reality is: The future is looking really encouraging.with real progress being made on a daily basis.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: 22 January 2026 RNS: BON-18 commenced in Bonasse Field. Expected to take two weeks to drill. Next well BON-19 to prove up BON-14 producing trend. (Started!) 5 to 7 shallow development wells in Bonasse to follow BON-19 Bonasse field between 200 and 300 bopd of new production will be added through existing facilities and oil sales arrangements. In the Goudron field a 6-8 Heavy Workover Program shall commence by next month, with the expectation of yielding an additional 100 bopd of new production through existing facilities and oil sales arrangements. The combined programmes are forecasted to add between 300 and 400 bopd. This will be added to the current production of 387bopd. Forecast up to 1,000 bopd and 5- to 10-fold increase in monthly revenues by end 2026. This was written prior to the placement. This is just on the NABI work-over's. What is important to note is that Predator have managed to turn a poorly run Trinidad operation into a profitable one. There are still a large amount of wells available to work on. Increase production and profit are now occurring in real time and show no indication of slowing down. A valid comment was that, prior to the fund raise, we were only receiving a small percentage of the profit. This suited the initial stage as NABI took all the risks. Now, with the likes of Snowcap-3 and our own rig we can run two operations at the same time. One is a steady build up and the other a massive step up in potential revenue. If Snowcap-3 is successful then Trinidad production level should supports a share price of 10/20 p. Calculation's were shown yesterday based on anticipated figures. Trinidad has had a proven record of oil production but in recent years it was badly run. Modern technology is showing that there is profit to be made. If we can achieve 1000 bopd , plus a potential 500/1000 bopd on SC-3 in such a short time then the future, and share value potential to increase is encouraging! Trinidad, on its own, has become a reason to purchase at today's share price! Progress is happening, but we need to wait for the developments to advance to see if Predator can achieve and we will need to see real flow figures before counting our chickens. It's certainly looking encouraging.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Thank you pv72,  your valuation gives us a great indication of how important Trinidad is. If we were to achieve the higher production of 1000bopd on SC-3 the revised figures would be: 1. NABI gets to 1000bopd, and we get 15% 2. SC-3  produced 1000bopd 3. We produce oil only for 300 days pa to allow for extended outages 4. Price per barrel at only $55 usd 5. PER at 10 6. $1.3=£1 1150x300x55x10÷1.3 gives us £146m market cap which gives us a top end of  17.9p per share in a success case. So a possable 10/20 p valuation is not too far off by Q4. These figures shows why PG decided to go down the placement route. If all goes well, this year, then Trinidad should drive up the value (Fingers crossed) What then? Continue to increase production? Increase production equals increase share price....... Or.... Sell? Until SC-3 is drilled and tested we can only hope that the production will be successful. It's easy to get carried away and patience is required. But.... The figures look good, NABI are ahead of Predator's target of the end of the year. Snowcap 2 and 3 are in proven regions. Interesting times ahead.

data.author: Gudin
data.content: PRD does not get 30%, that goes to Steeldrum which is split 51% PRD/ 49% WIEGL. The rns on January 21st 2025 clearly states they bought a 51% stake in CRL whose only asset was the bonasse field and there has been no further purchase of the remaining 49% released in an rns. The rns on 21st September 2025 clearly states the Goudron, Inniss trinity and Icacos holding companies would be transferred into  CRL which was renamed Steeldrum. In exchange for this 49% of the three CEG fields the 49% partner in Steeldrum WIEGL have taken on the $4.25m of liabilities from the CEG fields. PRD will be receiving 7.5% of production from bonasse, Goudron, Inniss trinity and Icacos fields until Nabi recover the costs , then they will revert to 15%. So if Nabi hit 1000bpd PRD will be receiving 7.5% of the 700 bpd increase which is 53bpd until costs are recovered and raising to 105 bpd when this had occurred.  Just for comparison PRD paid £2m for 282bpd of production to CEG, so valuations of ten times this for lower production is a bold claim. Even if the full 1000bpd is split between the two holders of Steeldrum then PRD will have 510 bpd  which is not quite twice the production they paid £2m for.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I fully expect NABI to achieve an oil production level of 1000 bopd later in the year. Predator receives 30% of gross sales revenues from existing production less taxes and royalties and 15% of new production until recovery of NABI costs, thereafter 30% of net sales revenues. We also have Snowcap  3 in the pipeline. This well has the potential to add 500/1000 bopd and unlike the NABI drills, this drill is financed by Predator with Predator keeping the profits. We will also be working on Snowcap 1. I'm not sure what we are expecting there. The current share price  is due to the placement price of 3.5p, with the MM's keeping it low to achieve maximum profit. Like all placement churns it will pass. I'm looking forward to receiving various RNS's, informing us of progress. The news, if positive, will add to the value. My personal opinion is that the NABI's production on its own would underpin the current share value, once the 1000 bopd target is achieved. Trinidad is an ongoing operation with multiple work overs still to undertake this year and next year? What  would the NABI work-over's and a successful SC-3 add to our share price? Is 10/20p a realistic figure? Obviously, it will depend on an successful SC-3. Just my take and I'd appreciate other posters's valuations and views. It does make today's price rather attract and may explain the troll activities at the weekend. We all like low buy-in prices! We also have news on Morocco to come.

I believe that buying at this price is a no brainer and I’m heavily invested because it believe in it. Others have their own opinion and may rightfully object but I just don’t see it not coming good and I feel like it will be this year we will see a substantial change for the better. If anything there is a slim chance something will come of it but think of it as a bonus if it does and if it doesn’t then so what right?

Instead, they'll dodge the questions, throw insults, and deflect—why might that be? • Short Selling or Hedging – They could be betting against the stock, hoping negative sentiment will drive the price down. • Emotional Investing – Some investors let emotions drive their decisions. If they feel betrayed by the company, they may be airing their grievances out of disappointment. • Competitive Bias – They hold stock in another company and genuinely believe their company is superior and see the competitor as a threat. • Personal or Professional Ties – They have direct involvement with another company, leading to bias against the competitor.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Morocco: MOU-6 well planning near finalisation. Mou-1: Formation gas shows were recorded in a shallow sand at 605 metres measured depth ("MD") comprising 2.35% or 19,392 ppm C1 methane. Total background, exclusively dry gas, increased from 0.6% to 1.7% (5,232 to 13,800 ppm C1) down to 1,159 metres MD. Formation gas shows of 1.8% and 3.8% (13,355 to 36,035 ppm C1) were encountered whilst drilling this section. Below 1,159 metres in the lower Guebbas and Hoot (using the stratigraphic nomenclature of the Rharb Basin) total background gas was from 0.7% to 1.5% (5,000 to 11,996 ppm C1) but with traces of heavier gases C2, C3 and C4. Formation gas shows of up to 1.67% (13,643 ppm total gases) were also recorded. Wireline logs were run from 724 to 1487.4 metres MD over the interval with gas shows. MOU-2 was drilled to 1,260 metres Measured Depth before being suspended for operational reasons for a possible later re-entry. THREE GAS samples collected whilst drilling. 100 metres of variable quality sand in primary target. MOU-3 was drilled to 1,509 metres Measured Depth and completed for rigless testing. SEVEN GAS samples collected whilst drilling. 50.5 metres of gross sand interval in primary target. Secondary targets Ma and TGB-6 sand intervals confirmed to be present and GAS- based on NuTech petrophysics and GAS samples collected whilst drilling. Ma and TGB-6 intervals correlated with MOU-1 drilled in 2021 to potentially define a single structure covering up to 21 km2. 11 metres of unexpected sand encountered at shallow depth with OVER-PRESSURISED GAS. Formation damage predicted due to necessity to drill with heavy drilling mud - to be potentially penetrated using Sandjet rigless testing technology. · MOU-4 was drilled to 1,199 metres Measured Depth and completed for rigless testing. Unexpected 58 metres of gross M1 Sand potential reservoir interval, interpreted by NuTech as GAS-BEARING . 21 metres of gross sand in primary target with improved reservoir characteristics compared to MOU-3 and interpreted as GAS-BEARING by NuTech petrophysics. I'm looking forward to the ITR... Trinidad update soon !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: Great post Keith ! The trolls are trying hard to fill this BB with FUD. Factual post like this harm the trolls agenda. They are unable to to analyse your post and respond with ignorance. ONHYM do not award licences. ONHYM and the company agree the terms necessary to award a licence. This was completed last year. The licence is awarded by the Energy Ministry, after sign off by the Finance Ministry. This is a contractual obligation. I am not aware of a single situation where ONHYM, or their predecessor ONAREP, has agreed licence terms then a licence is not issued. If you know of such an instance, please reference it. I have never said that a declaration of commerciality is up to Paul Griffiths “to make by himself “, so please do not distort my statements. I have made it crystal clear what specific events need to occur and be agreed before such declaration can be made – these constitute 3 of the 4 bullet points in my first post this morning, including commercial gas flow, a gas sales agreement and an FDP. So why suggest that I have not stated this when I have? I repeat, PG does have significant say on WHEN such declaration is made, and yes, the timing is driven by tax issues. Dr Tim Wright, FGS, FSEG, MIMMM of Scorpion Geosciences is an accredited Competent Person, meaning that he is deemed fully qualified and has direct personal experience of the necessary geological, geophysical and geotechnical aspects of this project. He is well known within the industry. It is a requirement that he has full and free access to whatever data has been generated. There is a lot of data. This same data will have been supplied to all companies and organisations (including ONHYM) for review by their own technical experts. I cannot possibly imagine that any credible potential partner would sign an agreement without doing their own very detailed Due Diligence. If there were to be significant discrepancies in their interpretation of the data compared to Scorpion's, that would be resolved by further discussion. Please detail the qualifications and experience that you have that put you in a reasonable position to question the veracity of past and forthcoming ITRs. I repeat that I had absolutely nothing to do with any 'Research Report' posted on this bulletin board. Anything I post is my own opinion, under my own name, based on publicly available information, which I usually reference. Potential investors should always check the facts behind any statement here. Please note that the Company has made it very clear that information on social media can be inadvertently or even deliberately misleading, and urged investors to rely only on statements in an RNS and the Company's official X account. I don't expect an apology - but if I said why I don't expect an apology, it would indeed be an insult, albeit a deserved one.

data.author: OlivettiChamp
data.content: Great response Keith - Very Much Apppreciated! On several occasions I have posted in response to certain individuals accusing me of making stuff up. My responses have then been rapidly removed by lse admin. I can only assume that the same certain people have attached offensive posts to the thread, resulting in the entire thread being removed - this classic troll technique has also been used against other posters here. The claim is then repeated and the cycle continues. A. In response that 'I refuse to admit that MOU-5 was a duster': Why would you put an expensive wellhead on a borehole that has not initially intersected hydrocarbons? Take a look at the top centre seismic chart on p.33 of the October presentation, and it should be obvious. 1). To further investigate the discovery of a Helium concentration of 3120 times the normal background level. 2). To appraise the intersected salt as a potential future gas storage medium, for which a separate ITR has been prepared. 3). To deepen by 1000m to delineate the boundary of the underlying 100kmº anticline of Triassic TAGI sands, which are sealed by a cap of impervious salt. B. With reference to delaying announcement of a commercial discovery in order to maximise tax exemption benefits. 1). It is correct that the standard ONHYM hydrocarbon contract states that the 10-year exemption from corporation tax begins upon commercialisation. However, the situation is more nuanced than this simple statement may seem to imply. I appreciate that nuance may be difficult for some to understand. 2). Upon the declaration of a commercial discovery, an Exploitation Concession must then be applied for within a defined period. This application must include timed and costed proposals to proceed to production. 3). Moroccan Hydrocarbon Code (Law No 21-90 and Decree No 2-93-786) then come into play. The concession can be revoked ("déchéance") for non-compliance, explicitly including "failure to timely complete development works and start operations." 4). It should be obvious that a company or its co-developers would not wish to prematurely announce a commercial discovery until it was in a position to be able to commence large scale production right from day 1, otherwise it would be losing serious amounts of tax benefits on the larger scale production likely in the later years of the exemption period. 5). PRD could have announced a commercial discovery a long time ago. They have not done so, and will not do so, until they have all the ducks in a row. These include * Completed quantification of available gas volumes. * Signed a definitive cooperation and gas sales agreement with an appropriate third party. * Ensured that a fully costed Field Development Plan is agreed. *The financial wherewithal and technical expertise are available to complete such an FDP. 6). The overarching reason for delaying announcement of a commercial discovery is for maximising tax benefits.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: predator oil & gas is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a compressed natural gas (cng) development project in morocco, focusing on the mou-3 well, which has shown potential for gas resources. the company is also preparing for a fully-funded environmental impact assessment for this cng development. energy-pedia.com **********.com overview of predator oil & gas in morocco predator oil & gas holdings is actively involved in the development of gas resources in morocco, particularly focusing on the guercif region. the company is working on a potential compressed natural gas (cng) project, which aims to monetize discovered gas reserves. current developments gas appraisal and development predator is in the final stages of partnership building and financial engineering for a final investment decision (fid) regarding gas appraisal and development. the mou-3 well has been identified as a key site for initial appraisal and potential development, focusing on the section above 950 meters. cng project plans discussions are ongoing with two parties for a fully-funded cng and/or micro-lng development. a fully-funded environmental impact assessment is set to commence for the cng/micro-lng development, along with preliminary engineering design concepts. financial position predator is fully funded to meet its commitments for the next twelve months, allowing it to accelerate its transition to production. the company has reported significant gas resources in the mou-1 and mou-3 wells, with estimates suggesting a potential standalone cng development project. future outlook the company aims to increase its production capacity and revenue through the successful implementation of its cng plans. the ongoing studies and testing are expected to enhance the understanding of gas saturations and improve the potential for gas resources in the region.

data.author: Tincan1995
data.content: Predator has an interesting gas project in Morocco with fast pace of commercialisation and significant upside. The Guercif project is a shallow CNG biogenic gas development with different traps and separate identified reservoirs. The Jurassic Titanosaurus is a shallow thermogenic gas prospect evaluating 249m of potential gross reservoir thickness in a trap of maximum closure of 187 km2 for pipeline gas to power, with pipeline 2.5km from wellhead. Moroccan gas prices are high, and the fiscal terms are some of the best in the world. data.content: Hey, Keith. Had a little look into hyperspectural satellites for hydrocarbons. I am so glad you are here to put many things in to small bite, layman’s terms. My head hurts Reading such as…. The radiometric calibration, atmospheric correction and orthorectification were done on ENVI + IDL (version 5.3) software (Harris Geospatial Solutions, Inc., Broomfield, CO, USA). The stripe noise removal was carried out by the full image stripe noise removal method (Tan et al., Citation2005). The calculation formula of this method is 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘=𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘+𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 /𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘= ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 −𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘⁢𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑚𝑘 , ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 = ¯ 𝑠𝑘 where 𝑥𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the radiation value of the i column and j line in the K band; 𝑥′ 𝑖⁢𝑗⁢𝑘 is the corrected radiation value; the 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column; 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, i column; ¯ 𝑚𝑖⁢𝑘 is the mean value of the K band, i column of the reference image; ¯ 𝑠𝑖⁢𝑘 is the standard deviation of the K band, the i column of the reference image. The 𝑎𝑖⁢𝑘 is the sensor gain and the 𝑏𝑖⁢𝑘 is the offset; ¯ 𝑚𝑘 is the mean value of the whole image in the K band; ¯ In plain English, Will  I be rich one day? 🤔 𝑠𝑘 is the mean standard deviation of the whole image in the K band.

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 2. Hyperspectral satellite data (which I have not seen, but I trust the interpretation I have been given) shows abundant gas underground in the whole area.  This data cannot indicate the depth of the gas source, so even were there no actual gas in the Jurassic, this suggests that the underlying Triassic is gas-charged. Across N. Africa, the TAGI is one of the most prolific sources of hydrocarbons.  It was known (from the above work by PG) to be at Tendrara.  Here the main TAGI is at a depth of 2600 – 2800m.  Well TE-6 shows 28m net of reservoir, TE-10 has 10m net, 110m gross.  TE-7 & TE-8 show hundreds of metres gross depth.  The problem is that at Tendrara the reservoir quality is poor, with 8% porosity, as opposed to up to 15% elsewhere.  This requires mechanical stimulation (fracking / acidizing) for commercial flow.  Interestingly, the same satellite data referred to above was ignored by SOU's James Parsons, resulting in the Tendrara drills being sub-optimally positioned. From what I can tell from the limited seismic data publicly available, the top of the Guercif Triassic is about 1000m closer to the surface than at Tendrara.  This will not only be cheaper to drill, but also likely to be less compacted, resulting in improved reservoir quality.  PG is probably the best qualified person on Earth to make that call, but I assume he has weighed up the cost : benefit potential for large, well sealed Triassic reservoirs as opposed to complex Jurassic structures, hence the change in near-term strategy. "When the facts change, I change my mind. What do you do, sir?" John Maynard Keynes.
data.thread_title: RE: Why the new emphasis on the Triassic?

data.author: KeithOz
data.content: Part 1. @MwoQ.  Great to see a new contributor, especially one asking an interesting question that I'm sure others have also wondered about. The view has been expressed on here by the usual suspects that there is no gas in the Jurassic, so 'bait & switch' has moved attention somewhere else, in this case the Triassic.  I don't agree with that, although of course what follows is my own personal interpretation. Paul Griffiths has a vastly more comprehensive view of these matters – after his MSc on 'Late Mesozoic seismic sequence stratigraphy of NE Libya' he worked for the Libyan National Oil Company and Gulf Oil evaluating exactly the potential reservoirs PRD are working on today.  Later in his career he worked up the initial evaluation of the TAGI opportunity at Tendrara, 125km south of Guercif, which will be producing for Sound / Mana later this year. First, we need to understand the complexity of the Jurassic carbonate.  The Titanosaurus structure is basically a huge fossil coral reef, laid down in waters of varying depth over millions of years.  When the water was deep, sediment would mostly be fine-grained, resulting in dense rock with poor hydrocarbon reservoir potential.  In shallow water, coral reef proper would form, and this rock, already of sponge-like texture, would be further eroded by periodic exposure to the air and/or waves.  This exposure results in leached porosity development - which means what it says – increased pores and cavities resulting in excellent capacity as a hydrocarbon reservoir.  From this, it can be seen there will be vertically stacked high potential reservoirs alternating with non-productive strata.  Added to this complexity is the likelihood of horizontal variation – think of many reefs separated by infilled channels. Directly beneath the Jurassic is the top of the Triassic – marked by a thick layer of salt resulting from the evaporation of part of the ancient Tethys Sea, of which the Med forms a small remnant.  This salt acts as a very viscous liquid, moving upwards and sideways due to the pressure of overlying rock. This layer is impervious to gas, so forms an excellent seal for any gas reservoirs beneath.  However, the seismic wave conduction velocities of rock salt and carbonate reservoir are very similar, making them difficult to distinguish. The seismic data available to PRD is not that great, tbh. As a result, MOU-5 was drilled into a laterally mobilised salt layer, not carbonate reservoir.  It seems that the particular part of Titanosaurus that was drilled has been isolated from gas migration by salt above, below and laterally.  Correlation of drilled material with the seismic data has resulted in a greatly improved understanding of the structure.  There is every possibility that the structure contains multiple TCF of gas, but will require more detailed geophysical evaluation, which will cost more than PRD can afford – hence the farm in process currently underway.

data.author: JoshW7
data.content: Welcome to the board ManWithoutQual. Rather like you I'm no O&G expert either, my take on your question is Predator’s recent messaging emphasises the TAGI reservoirs rather than the Jurassic, not because the Jurassic has lost value but because TAGI offers a faster, lower‑risk route to commercial gas. TAGI wells are shallower and cheaper to drill. The Jurassic remains a large, high‑impact target, but drilling it requires more capital, deeper wells, and potentially a partner. By proving TAGI commerciality first, Predator strengthens its negotiating position and de‑risks the basin. The shift is strategic sequencing: TAGI now, Jurassic later as the transformational upside. I'm sure others will chip in with their take on it too but that's my starter for 10.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: I did find this from TW’s  copilot: “Here’s a clear, trader‑level breakdown of what the order book was almost certainly doing today. 📘 Level 2 Behaviour Assessment for PRD.L (Today) 🧩 1. Tight Spread = Balanced Book PRD.L traded in a very narrow range (3.40p–3.50p) with the mid-price barely moving. A tight spread like that usually means: Market makers were well-supplied on both sides No aggressive buyers lifting the ask No aggressive sellers hitting the bid This is classic neutral order book behaviour. 📈 2. High Volume, No Price Movement = Absorption Volume was 3× the daily average, yet the price barely moved. That strongly suggests: Large buy orders were being absorbed by resting sell liquidity, or Large sell orders were being absorbed by resting buy liquidity This is called absorption, and it’s a hallmark of: Accumulation Distribution Position rotation Market makers managing inventory If this were retail-driven volume, the price would have moved more. 🧱 3. Likely Large Iceberg Orders When you see: High volume Flat price Tight spread …it often means iceberg orders (hidden size) were sitting at key levels. Most likely: 3.40p had a large hidden buyer 3.50p had a large hidden seller This creates a “volume box” where price gets trapped. 🔄 4. Repeated Prints at the Same Price This pattern usually indicates: Market makers refreshing orders Algo participation Institutional accumulation/distribution If you saw lots of trades at 3.45p–3.48p, that’s a sign of: VWAP algos TWAP algos Liquidity-seeking algos These keep the price pinned. 🧭 5. What This Means for Traders This type of order book behaviour usually precedes one of two things: Scenario A — Accumulation If buyers were absorbing sells: Price will break upward once the seller is cleared Volume spike with no drop is bullish Scenario B — Distribution If sellers were absorbing buys: Price will break downward once the buyer is filled Volume spike with no rise is bearish Right now, the book behaviour is neutral-to-accumulative, because: Price did not weaken despite heavy volume No sign of bid collapse No widening spreads That leans slightly bullish. 🎯 Summary Today’s Level 2 behaviour for PRD.L likely showed: Tight spreads Heavy liquidity at 3.40p and 3.50p Iceberg orders absorbing flow Market makers keeping price boxed High volume without directional movement This is classic positioning ahead of news or institutional accumulation.”

data.author: ManWithoutQual
data.content: I'm a long time lurker on this board who has decided to finally jump into the arena. I first invested in PRD after the MOU-2 drill, so while I haven't been involved in PRD as long as some posters, I do have my fair share of scars! I've been accumulating steadily since MOU-2 and have amassed 1.3 million shares. While this may be a pittance compared to others, PRD is my largest single company investment so it matters a great deal to me and I take it seriously. Over the last several years I have been working consistently to gain a better understanding of my investment and I deeply appreciate the knowledgeable contributions of so many posters here. I am neither a financial expert or advisor nor am I an oil and gas expert, I've spent my career building software (including AI before it became the Messiah), but I love to learn and find the whole oil and gas sector utterly fascinating. My interest was first peaked during the shale boom when I was working at a cloud company in Texas and we kicked off a number of discussions with O&G producers about utilizing Permian and Eagle Ford gas to power our data centers. I realize that the sentiment here isn't great after the most recent raise. I confess to have taken it as a gut punch initially. I was expecting the next RNS to be the new ITR and based on the 17 December 2025 "End of Year Operations Update" I was not expecting a placement for any Trinidad operations. But any placing is only dilutive if it's not ultimately accretive. Raising money to engage in operations that have revenue potential is far different from raising money for general corporate purposes. I understand how frustrating delays can be - 2024 and 2025 tried my patience severely - but I am also a student of history, and it strikes me that oil and gas discovery, appraisal, and development is rarely the untrammeled movement from success to success. Pick a field, dig into its history, and you will see that more often than not. Now that I've pontificated enough, I'm onto my question: it seems as though the Jurassic potential is no longer being highlighted despite the fact that there may be untapped potential in other parts of the structure. Instead, the Company is focusing more on the TAGI. Would be interested to hear the opinions of others on the subject. Thanks.

data.author: ParetoPrinciple
data.content: Sorry Rob. Good find! Found this part interesting! What the placing changes: From a market perspective, the raise alters the near-term picture in several practical ways. Key takeaways post-placing Near-term work programme funded Capital raised ahead of activity, not in response to it Reduced financing overhang during an active operational period Newsflow expected across multiple operations rather than a single event Predator retains 100% ownership of Snowcap-3, maintaining full exposure to any upside The Trinidad programme is sequenced, with multiple wells and workovers planned rather than a one-off Historical flow data combined with improved well placement underpins the Snowcap-3 appraisal rationale Taken together, this shifts the focus from funding uncertainty toward execution. Before any formal appraisal outcome, investors would typically expect a sequence of operational updates rather than a single standalone result. This often includes: Initial drilling update Confirmation of spud Progress toward target depth Early operational observations, where relevant Logging and reservoir evaluation Confirmation that logs have been run Initial indications of reservoir thickness and quality Commentary that is often qualitative rather than fully quantified at first Operational / testing update Flow testing plans or results (if undertaken) Completion status Decisions around tie-in or next operational steps Interesting times ahead !

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I note an increase of filtered posts, so a  reminder of where we are. Trinidad: With the last update, the existing production was 387bopd. Forecasted production is an addition 350/400 bopd. That makes 737/787bopd. That's just the work over the next six to eight weeks by NABI. There will also be revenue from Snowcap 3 shortly. Testing results early Q3. The flow rate is expected to be between 500/1000 bopd, resulting in a revenue, per month, of one/two million. This revenue will not be shared with NABI and is the main reason for the fund raise. The revenue from Snowcap 3 should  quickly recover the placement money. Predator will be using their own T38 refurbished rig. There will then be 2 rigs and teams pushing on with work-overs and new drills! 2000bopd is very doable in the near future. Morocco: We await updated reports and news on negotiations January/February: An updated Independent Technical Resources report ,which will take into consideration the studies completed in 2025, is likely to uplift gas resources for the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure. Validation of the NuTech interpretation of gas saturations is also likely to significantly increase potential for prospective gas resources beyond the limits of the MOU-1 and MOU-3 structure in the interval down to 950 metres. A fully-funded Environmental Impact Assessment will be commenced for a CNG/micro-LNG development together with a preliminary Front End Engineering Design concept. Desktop well design and drilling programme will be finalised for an appraisal/development well. The purpose of the fully-funded desktop work during this period is to ensure that the Company and its shareholders get the best possible mutually acceptable terms in commercial negotiations to monetise the discovered gas with the existing entities agreeing to join the Company in a potential FID and development programme. ‌A successful application for an Exploitation Concession in 2026 will crystalise the considerable value currently assigned to the discovered gas in Guercif licence area. Nothing is certain but Predator are moving forward with confidence. There will be a few weeks of churning the placement shares. The unwashed  will do their best to spread panic and fear. However, the reality is: The future is looking really encouraging.with real progress being made on a daily basis.

data.author: Gudin
data.content: Due to the limited flow data any projections have to be conservative Matt. The extended well test at Snowcap 1 in Q3 2012 flowed 150 - 200bpd before being terminated early due to wax so there is little information to work with. It appears that the H#8 sands have the best initial flowrates of 1000bpd, the other sands ranged from H#6 at 16bpd to H#7 at 432bpd.

data.author: Gudin
data.content: Keith posted recently about the high decline rates prevalent in T&T, which posters who usually hang on his every word have ignored for some reason in their production and revenue forecasts. The January 2025 presentation page 18 has Snowcap 1 starting at 200bpd falling to 75bpd after one quarter. The estimated revenue at $68 wti for the first quarter at an initial 200bpd is $600k falling to $200k in the second quarter. 500bpd for Snowcap 3 using similar figures would give q1 at $1.5m and Q2 falling to $500k, a significant decrease in the figures some are using. PRD plan on using wax treatment, the performance in T&T is unknown and the cost of the system has not been released so it is difficult to produce estimates until these are determined. https://wp-predatoroilandgas-2024.s3.eu-west-2.amazonaws.com/media/2025/01/Corporate-Presentation-21-JANUARY-2025.pdf

data.author: Rustyrat1970
data.content: Here's how the 2026 timeline shapes up based on what they've laid out (Using AI, interesting ): Q1 2026 (now — happening) -BON-18 in Bonasse started drilling 20 January, was expected to take about 2 weeks — so results from that should be imminent or possibly already in. -BON-19 exploratory well follows straight after. - Up to 12 new wells and 14 heavy workovers scheduled through H1, so this is an intense drilling period with NABI Energy-Pedia - Ongoing production updates as they work through the infield programme — expect regular RNS announcements as wells come on stream Q2 2026 — the big one - Snowcap-3 is scheduled for Q2, expected to take around 20 days to drill and log down to approximately 5,300 feet. - it's targeting those 8 Herrera reservoir sands and the 56.9m barrel 3P resource. The original Snowcap-1 well flowed at initial rates of 1,100 to 1,450 bopd before stabilising at 500 bopd , so if SC-3 hits properly it could be genuinely transformational for the production profile Q3 2026 - SC-3 is intended to be put into production in Q3 after drilling and testing completes - Morocco — targeting completion of work necessary for an Exploitation Concession application by end of Q3 , which would crystallise the value of the discovered gas at Guercif JV partnering discussions for Morocco should be progressing through this period too H2 / Year-end 2026 -The overall target is to exit 2026 at 1,000 bopd, which they estimate would generate a five to ten fold increase in monthly production revenues v $100k/month they were averaging in late 2025 - Earnings expected around April 2026 So realistically, the next few weeks should bring news on the Bonasse wells, then the real share price catalyst is Snowcap-3 results in Q2/Q3.  If SC-3 delivers anything close to what Snowcap-1 did, the production and revenue numbers change dramatically. If it disappoints, it's a very different story at 3.3p with diluted shares outstanding.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: 22 January 2026 RNS: BON-18 commenced in Bonasse Field. Expected to take two weeks to drill. Next well BON-19 to prove up BON-14 producing trend. (Started!) 5 to 7 shallow development wells in Bonasse to follow BON-19 Bonasse field between 200 and 300 bopd of new production will be added through existing facilities and oil sales arrangements. In the Goudron field a 6-8 Heavy Workover Program shall commence by next month, with the expectation of yielding an additional 100 bopd of new production through existing facilities and oil sales arrangements. The combined programmes are forecasted to add between 300 and 400 bopd. This will be added to the current production of 387bopd. Forecast up to 1,000 bopd and 5- to 10-fold increase in monthly revenues by end 2026. This was written prior to the placement. This is just on the NABI work-over's. What is important to note is that Predator have managed to turn a poorly run Trinidad operation into a profitable one. There are still a large amount of wells available to work on. Increase production and profit are now occurring in real time and show no indication of slowing down. A valid comment was that, prior to the fund raise, we were only receiving a small percentage of the profit. This suited the initial stage as NABI took all the risks. Now, with the likes of Snowcap-3 and our own rig we can run two operations at the same time. One is a steady build up and the other a massive step up in potential revenue. If Snowcap-3 is successful then Trinidad production level should supports a share price of 10/20 p. Calculation's were shown yesterday based on anticipated figures. Trinidad has had a proven record of oil production but in recent years it was badly run. Modern technology is showing that there is profit to be made. If we can achieve 1000 bopd , plus a potential 500/1000 bopd on SC-3 in such a short time then the future, and share value potential to increase is encouraging! Trinidad, on its own, has become a reason to purchase at today's share price! Progress is happening, but we need to wait for the developments to advance to see if Predator can achieve and we will need to see real flow figures before counting our chickens. It's certainly looking encouraging.

data.author: Gudin
data.content: PRD does not get 30%, that goes to Steeldrum which is split 51% PRD/ 49% WIEGL. The rns on January 21st 2025 clearly states they bought a 51% stake in CRL whose only asset was the bonasse field and there has been no further purchase of the remaining 49% released in an rns. The rns on 21st September 2025 clearly states the Goudron, Inniss trinity and Icacos holding companies would be transferred into  CRL which was renamed Steeldrum. In exchange for this 49% of the three CEG fields the 49% partner in Steeldrum WIEGL have taken on the $4.25m of liabilities from the CEG fields. PRD will be receiving 7.5% of production from bonasse, Goudron, Inniss trinity and Icacos fields until Nabi recover the costs , then they will revert to 15%. So if Nabi hit 1000bpd PRD will be receiving 7.5% of the 700 bpd increase which is 53bpd until costs are recovered and raising to 105 bpd when this had occurred.  Just for comparison PRD paid £2m for 282bpd of production to CEG, so valuations of ten times this for lower production is a bold claim. Even if the full 1000bpd is split between the two holders of Steeldrum then PRD will have 510 bpd  which is not quite twice the production they paid £2m for.

data.author: Madman-Rob
data.content: I fully expect NABI to achieve an oil production level of 1000 bopd later in the year. Predator receives 30% of gross sales revenues from existing production less taxes and royalties and 15% of new production until recovery of NABI costs, thereafter 30% of net sales revenues. We also have Snowcap  3 in the pipeline. This well has the potential to add 500/1000 bopd and unlike the NABI drills, this drill is financed by Predator with Predator keeping the profits. We will also be working on Snowcap 1. I'm not sure what we are expecting there. The current share price  is due to the placement price of 3.5p, with the MM's keeping it low to achieve maximum profit. Like all placement churns it will pass. I'm looking forward to receiving various RNS's, informing us of progress. The news, if positive, will add to the value. My personal opinion is that the NABI's production on its own would underpin the current share value, once the 1000 bopd target is achieved. Trinidad is an ongoing operation with multiple work overs still to undertake this year and next year? What  would the NABI work-over's and a successful SC-3 add to our share price? Is 10/20p a realistic figure? Obviously, it will depend on an successful SC-3. Just my take and I'd appreciate other posters's valuations and views. It does make today's price rather attract and may explain the troll activities at the weekend. We all like low buy-in prices! We also have news on Morocco to come.
